That cult films can have opposing qualities – such as good and bad, failure and success, innovative and retro – helps to illustrate that art is subjective and never self-evident.<ref name=cineaste>{{cite journal|last1=Church |first1=David |last2=Hills |first2=Matt |last3=Hunter |first3=I. Q. |last4=Kleinhans |first4=Chuck |last5=Koven |first5=Mikel J. |last6=Mathijs |first6=Ernest |last7=Rosenbaum |first7=Jonathan |last8=Weinstock |first8=Jeffrey Andrew |title=Cult Film: A Critical Symposium (Web Edition) |url=http://www.cineaste.com/articles/cult-film-a-critical-symposium |work=[[Cineaste (magazine)|Cineaste]] |accessdate=2013-05-09 |volume=34 |issue=1 |year=2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130828161957/http://www.cineaste.com/articles/cult-film-a-critical-symposium |archivedate=August 28, 2013 |df=mdy }}</ref> This ambiguity leads critics of [[postmodernism]] to accuse cult films of being beyond criticism, as the emphasis is now on personal interpretation rather than critical analysis or [[metanarrative]]s.<ref name=shiel /> These inherent dichotomies can lead audiences to be split between ironic and earnest fans.<ref>{{cite news|last=Anderson|first=Jason|title=Cult horror House finally finds home in Toronto|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/movies/2010/07/22/cult_horror_house_finally_finds_home_in_toronto.html|accessdate=2013-05-19|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|date=2010-07-22}}</ref>
Writing in ''Defining Cult Movies'', Jancovich et al. quote academic Jeffrey Sconce, who defines cult films in terms of [[paracinema]], marginal films that exist outside critical and cultural acceptance: everything from exploitation to beach party musicals to softcore pornography. However, they reject cult films as having a single unifying feature; instead, they state that cult films are united in their "subcultural ideology" and opposition to mainstream tastes, itself a vague and undefinable term. Cult followings themselves can range from adoration to contempt, and they have little in common except for their celebration of nonconformity – even the bad films ridiculed by fans are artistically nonconformist, albeit unintentionally. At the same time, they state that bourgeois, masculine tastes are frequently reinforced, which makes cult films more of an internal conflict within the bourgeoisie, rather than a rebellion against it. This results in an anti-academic bias despite the use of formal methodologies, such as [[defamiliarization]].<ref name="cult-intro">{{cite book|title=Defining Cult Movies: The Cultural Politics of Oppositional Taste|last1=Jancovich|first1=Mark|last2=Reboll|first2=Antonio Làzaro|last3=Stringer|first3=Julian|last4=Willis|first4=Andy|year=2003|publisher=[[Manchester University Press]]|location=Manchester|isbn=978-0-7190-6631-3|pages=1–3|chapter=Introduction}}</ref> This contradiction exists in many subcultures, especially those dependent on defining themselves in terms of opposition to the mainstream. This nonconformity is eventually co-opted by the dominant forces, such as Hollywood, and marketed to the mainstream.<ref name=alamo>{{cite journal| last=de Ville| first=Donna| title=Cultivating the Cult Experience at the Alamo Drafthouse Cinema| journal=Scope| year=2011| issue=20| url=http://www.scope.nottingham.ac.uk/article.php?issue=20&id=1306|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130622155957/http://www.scope.nottingham.ac.uk/article.php?issue=20&id=1306|archivedate=2013-06-22|accessdate=2013-06-04| issn=1465-9166}}</ref> Academic [[Xavier Mendik]] also defines cult films as opposing the mainstream and further proposes that films can become cult by virtue of their genre or content, especially if it is transgressive. Due to their rejection of mainstream appeal, Mendik says cult films can be more creative and political; times of relative political instability produce more interesting films.<ref name=sheep>{{cite journal|last=Sélavy|first=Virginie|title=Interview with Xavier Mendik|journal=Electric Sheep|date=2008-05-01|url=http://www.electricsheepmagazine.co.uk/features/2008/05/01/interview-with-xavier-mendik/|accessdate=2013-06-28}}</ref>
==General overview== Cult films have existed since the early days of cinema. Film critic Harry Allan Potamkin traces them back to 1910s France and the reception of [[Pearl White]], [[William S. Hart]], and [[Charlie Chaplin]], which he described as "a dissent from the popular ritual".<ref>{{cite book|title=The Cult Film Reader|last=Potamkin|first=Harry Allen|editor1-last=Mathijs|editor1-first=Ernest|editor2-last=Mendik|editor2-first=Xavier|publisher=[[McGraw-Hill International]]|year=2007|isbn=978-0-335-21923-0|page=26|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dWX4AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA26|chapter=Film Cults}}</ref> ''[[Nosferatu]]'' (1922) was an unauthorized adaptation of [[Bram Stoker]]'s ''[[Dracula (novel)|Dracula]]''. Stoker's widow sued the production company and drove it to bankruptcy. All known copies of the film were destroyed, and ''Nosferatu'' become an early cult film, kept alive by a cult following that circulated illegal bootlegs.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hall|first=Phil|title=The Bootleg Files: "Nosferatu"|url=http://www.filmthreat.com/features/2056/|work=[[Film Threat]]|accessdate=2013-04-29|authorlink=Phil Hall (US writer)|date=2007-10-26}}</ref> Academic Chuck Kleinhans identifies the [[Marx Brothers]] as making other early cult films.<ref name=cineaste /> On their original release, some highly regarded classics from the [[Golden Age of Hollywood]] were panned by critics and audiences, relegated to cult status. ''[[The Night of the Hunter (film)|The Night of the Hunter]]'' (1955) was a cult film for years, quoted often and championed by fans, before it was reassessed as an important and influential classic.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ventura|first=Elbert|title=The Greatest One-Off in Movie History|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/dvdextras/2010/11/the_greatest_oneoff_in_movie_history.html|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|accessdate=2013-04-24|date=2010-11-09}}</ref> During this time, American [[exploitation film]]s and imported European [[art film]]s were marketed similarly. Although critics [[Pauline Kael]] and [[Arthur Knight (film critic)|Arthur Knight]] argued against arbitrary divisions into [[high culture|high]] and [[low culture]], American films settled into rigid genres; European art films continued to push the boundaries of simple definitions, and these exploitative art films and artistic exploitation films would go on to influence American cult films.<ref name=betz>{{cite book| last=Betz| first=Mark| title=Defining Cult Movies: the Cultural Politics of Oppositional Taste| year=2003| publisher=[[Manchester University Press]]| location=Manchester| isbn=978-0-7190-6631-3| editor1-last=Jancovich| editor1-first=Mark| editor2-last=Reboll| editor2-first=Antionio Lázaro| editor3-last=Stringer| editor3-first=Julian| editor4-last=Willis| editor4-first=Andy| chapter=Art, Exploitation, and Underground}}</ref>{{rp|202–205}} Much like later cult films, these early exploitation films encouraged audience participation, influenced by live theater and vaudeville.<ref name=alamo />
Modern cult films grew from 1960s [[counterculture]] and [[underground film]]s, popular among those who rejected mainstream Hollywood films. These underground film festivals led to the creation of [[midnight movie]]s, which attracted cult followings.<ref>{{cite news|last=Patterson|first=John|title=The Weirdo Element|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2007/mar/02/5|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=2013-04-27|date=2007-03-01}}</ref> The term ''cult film'' itself was an outgrowth of this movement and was first used in the 1970s,<ref>{{cite book|title=Cult Cinema|last1=Mathijs|first1=Ernest|last2=Sexton|first2=Jamie|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]|year=2011|isbn=978-1-4051-7374-2|page=234|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ntg-1SAKgboC&pg=PA234|chapter=Meta-cult}}</ref> though ''cult'' had been in use for decades in film analysis with both positive and negative connotations.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Cult Film Reader|last1=Mathijs|first1=Ernest|last2=Mendik|first2=Xavier|publisher=[[McGraw-Hill International]]|year=2007|isbn=978-0-335-21923-0|page=19|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dWX4AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA19}}</ref> These films were more concerned with cultural significance than the social justice sought by earlier [[avant-garde film]]s.<ref name=shiel /> Midnight movies became more popular and mainstream, peaking with the release of ''[[The Rocky Horror Picture Show]]'' (1975), which finally found its audience several years after its release. Eventually, the rise of home video would marginalize midnight movies once again, after which many directors joined the burgeoning [[independent film]] scene or went back underground.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mathijs|first1=Ernest|last2=Sexton|first2=Jamie|title=Cult Cinema|year=2011|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]|isbn=978-1-4443-9643-0|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uPtuaV7IAt0C&pg=PT27|chapter=Cult Movie Contexts: Midnight Movies|location=Malden, MA}}</ref> Home video would give a second life to box office flops, as positive [[word-of-mouth]] or excessive replay on cable television led these films to develop an appreciative audience,<ref name="cult-dead">{{cite news|last=Kirkland|first=Bruce|title=Cult Movies Are All But Dead|url=http://www.torontosun.com/2013/04/05/cult-movies-are-all-but-dead|work=[[Toronto Sun]]|accessdate=2013-04-27|date=2013-04-08}}</ref> as well as obsessive replay and study.<ref>{{cite news|last=Pevere|first=Geoff|title=Room 237, The Shining and Our Obsession with Cult Films|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/film/room-237-the-shining-and-our-obsession-with-cult-films/article11816475/|accessdate=2013-05-14|newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=2013-05-13}}</ref> For example, ''[[The Beastmaster]]'' (1982), despite its failure at the box office, became one of the most played movies on American cable television<ref>{{cite journal|last=Browne|first=David|title=Dar He Goes Again|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,307943,00.html|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=2013-05-06|date=1993-09-10|issue=187}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Hicks|first=Chris|title="Beastmaster" Actor Has Kept Busy|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/180144/BEASTMASTER-ACTOR-HAS-KEPT-BUSY.html|accessdate=2013-05-06|newspaper=[[Deseret News]]|date=1991-08-28}}</ref> and developed into a cult film.<ref name="bbc-cult" /> Home video and television broadcasts of cult films were initially greeted with hostility. Joanne Hollows states that they were seen as turning cult films mainstream – in effect, feminizing them by opening them to distracted, passive audiences.<ref name=hollows />{{rp|42–43}}
[[File:Moore and Bridges Lebowskifest.jpg|thumb|alt=Julianne Moore and Jeff Bridges sitting down in front of a poster of The Big Lebowski|[[Julianne Moore]] and [[Jeff Bridges]] at [[Lebowski Fest]] 2011]]
Releases from major studios – such as ''[[The Big Lebowski]]'' (1998), which was distributed by [[Universal Studios]] – can become cult films when they fail at the box office and develop a cult following through reissues, such as midnight movies, festivals, and home video. Hollywood films, due to their nature, are more likely to attract this kind of attention, which leads to a mainstreaming effect of cult culture. With major studios behind them, even financially unsuccessful films can be re-released multiple times, which plays into a trend to capture audiences through repetitious reissues. The constant use of profanity and drugs in otherwise mainstream, Hollywood films, such as ''The Big Lebowski'', can alienate critics and audiences yet lead to a large cult following among more open-minded demographics not often associated with cult films, such as Wall Street bankers and professional soldiers. Thus, even comparatively mainstream films can satisfy the traditional demands of a cult film, perceived by fans as transgressive, niche, and uncommercial.<ref>{{cite web|last=Klinger|first=Barbara|title=Becoming Cult: The Big Lebowski, Replay Culture and Male Fans|url=http://library.uoregon.edu/sites/default/files/data/guides/english/klinger_lebowski.pdf|work=[[University of Oregon]]|accessdate=2013-05-11}}</ref> Discussing his reputation for making cult films, [[Bollywood]] director [[Anurag Kashyap]] said, "I didn't set out to make cult films. I wanted to make box-office hits."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://india.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/01/21/newswallah-bollywood-edition-9/|title=Newswallah: Bollywood Edition|last=Chopra|first=Anupama|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2011-01-21|accessdate=2014-06-07}}</ref> Writing in ''Cult Cinema'', academics Ernest Mathijs and Jamie Sexton state that this acceptance of mainstream culture and commercialism is not out of character, as cult audiences have a more complex relationship to these concepts: they are more opposed to mainstream values and excessive commercialism than they are anything else.<ref>{{cite book|title=Cult Cinema|last1=Mathijs|first=Ernest|last2=Sexton|first2=Jamie|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]|year=2012|isbn=978-1-4443-9642-3|pages=62–63|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3EmSqIo4I-QC&pg=PA62|chapter=Fandom and Subculture}}</ref>
In a global context, popularity can vary widely by territory, especially with regard to limited releases. ''[[Mad Max]]'' (1979) was an international hit – except in America<ref>{{cite web|last=Smith|first=Richard Harland|title=Mad Max|url=http://www.tcm.com/this-month/article/160862%7C0/Mad-Max.html|work=[[Turner Classic Movies]]|accessdate=2013-05-17}}</ref> where it became an obscure cult favorite, ignored by critics and available for years only in a dubbed version though it earned over $100M internationally.<ref>{{cite web|last=Berardinelli|first=James|title=Mad Max|url=http://preview.reelviews.net/movies/m/mad_max.html|work=Reelviews|accessdate=2013-05-17|authorlink=James Berardinelli}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Barra|first=Allen|title=FILM; A Road Warrior Is Still on a Roll|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/08/15/movies/film-a-road-warrior-is-still-on-a-roll.html|accessdate=2013-05-17|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=1999-08-15|authorlink=Allen Barra}}</ref> Foreign cinema can put a different spin on popular genres, such as [[Japanese horror]], which was initially a cult favorite in America.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hollywood Takes a Chance on J-Horror Films|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2006-06-23/features/0606230021_1_horror-tartan-remakes|accessdate=2013-05-20|newspaper=[[Baltimore Sun]]|date=2006-06-23|agency=[[Knight Ridder]]}}</ref> Asian imports to the West are often marketed as exotic cult films and of interchangeable national identity, which academic Chi-Yun Shin criticizes as reductive.<ref name=extreme>{{cite journal|last=Shin|first=Chi-Yun|title=Art of Branding: Tartan "Asia Extreme" Films|journal=[[Jump Cut (journal)|Jump Cut]]|year=2008|issue=50|url=http://www.ejumpcut.org/archive/jc50.2008/TartanDist/index.html|accessdate=2013-05-22}}</ref> Foreign influence can affect fan response, especially on genres tied to a national identity; when they become more global in scope, questions of authenticity may arise.<ref name=hunt>{{cite book| last=Hunt| first=Leon| title=Defining Cult Movies: the Cultural Politics of Oppositional Taste| year=2003| publisher=[[Manchester University Press]]| location=Manchester| isbn=978-0-7190-6631-3| editor1-last=Jancovich| editor1-first=Mark| editor2-last=Reboll| editor2-first=Antionio Lázaro| editor3-last=Stringer| editor3-first=Julian| editor4-last=Willis| editor4-first=Andy| chapter=Kung Fu Cult Masters}}</ref>{{rp|157–160}} Filmmakers and films ignored in their own country can become the objects of cult adoration in another, producing perplexed reactions in their native country.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stanley|first=Alessandra|title=Can 50 Million Frenchmen Be Wrong?|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/21/magazine/can-50-million-frenchmen-be-wrong.html|accessdate=2013-06-03|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=1990-10-21|authorlink=Alessandra Stanley}}</ref> Cult films can also establish an early viability for more mainstream films both for filmmakers and national cinema. The early cult horror films of [[Peter Jackson]] were so strongly associated with his homeland that they affected the international reputation of New Zealand and [[Cinema of New Zealand|its cinema]]. As more artistic films emerged, New Zealand was perceived as a legitimate competitor to Hollywood, which mirrored Jackson's career trajectory. ''[[Heavenly Creatures]]'' (1994) acquired its own cult following, became a part of New Zealand's national identity, and paved the way for big-budget, Hollywood-style epics, such as Jackson's ''[[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|Lord of the Rings]]'' trilogy.<ref>{{cite book| last=Wu| first=Harmony H.| title=Defining Cult Movies: the Cultural Politics of Oppositional Taste| year=2003| publisher=[[Manchester University Press]]| location=Manchester| isbn=978-0-7190-6631-3| editor1-last=Jancovich| editor1-first=Mark| editor2-last=Reboll| editor2-first=Antionio Lázaro| editor3-last=Stringer| editor3-first=Julian| editor4-last=Willis| editor4-first=Andy| pages=84–104| chapter=Trading in Horror, Cult, and Matricide}}</ref>
Mathijs states that cult films and fandom frequently involve nontraditional elements of time and time management. Fans will often watch films obsessively, an activity that is viewed by the mainstream as wasting time yet can be seen as resisting the commodification of leisure time. They may also watch films idiosyncratically: sped up, slowed down, frequently paused, or at odd hours. Cult films themselves subvert traditional views of time – time travel, non-linear narratives, and ambiguous establishments of time are all popular. Mathijs also identifies specific cult film viewing habits, such as viewing horror films on Halloween, sentimental melodrama on Christmas, and romantic films on Valentine's Day. These films are often viewed as marathons where fans can gorge themselves on their favorites.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Mathijs|first=Ernest|title=Time Wasted|journal=[[Flow (journal)|Flow]]|date=2010-03-29|volume=11|issue=10|url=http://flowtv.org/2010/03/time-wasted-ernest-mathijs-the-university-of-british-columbia/|accessdate=2013-06-19}}</ref> Mathijs states that cult films broadcast on Christmas have a nostalgic factor. These films, ritually watched every season, give a sense of community and shared nostalgia to viewers. New films often have trouble making inroads against the institutions of ''[[It's A Wonderful Life]]'' (1946) and ''[[Miracle on 34th Street]]'' (1947). These films provide mild criticism of consumerism while encouraging family values.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Mathijs|first=Ernest|title=Television and the Yuletide Cult|journal=[[Flow (journal)|Flow]]|date=2010-01-08|volume=11|issue=5|url=http://flowtv.org/2010/01/television-and-the-yuletide-cult-ernest-mathijs-the-university-of-british-columbia/|accessdate=2013-06-19}}</ref> Halloween, on the other hand, allows flaunting society's taboos and testing one's fears. Horror films have appropriated the holiday, and many horror films debut on Halloween. Mathijs criticizes the over-cultified, commercialized nature of Halloween and horror films, which feed into each other so much that Halloween has turned into an image or product with no real community. Mathijs states that Halloween horror conventions can provide the missing community aspect.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Mathijs|first=Ernest|title=Threat or Treat: Film, Television, and the Ritual of Halloween|journal=[[Flow (journal)|Flow]]|date=2009-10-30|volume=11|issue=1|url=http://flowtv.org/2009/10/threat-or-treat-film-television-and-the-ritual-of-halloween-ernest-mathijs-the-university-of-british-columbia/|accessdate=2013-06-19}}</ref>
Despite their oppositional nature, cult films can produce celebrities. Like cult films themselves, authenticity is an important aspect of their popularity.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Egan|first1=Kate|last2=Thomas|first2=Sarah|title=Cult Film Stardom: Offbeat Attractions and Processes of Cultification|year=2012|publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]]|isbn=978-1-137-29177-6|pages=1–2, 7|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x2hQSUYG7RQC&pg=PA1|chapter=Introduction}}</ref> Actors can become typecast as they become strongly associated with such iconic roles. [[Tim Curry]], despite his acknowledged range as an actor, found casting difficult after he achieved fame in ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show''. Even when discussing unrelated projects, interviewers frequently bring up the role, which causes him to tire of discussing it.<ref>{{cite news|last=Davis|first=Sandi|title=Animated Roles Help Actor Skip Stereotype|url=http://newsok.com/animated-roles-help-actor-skip-stereotype/article/2819410|accessdate=2013-06-04|newspaper=[[The Oklahoman]]|date=2002-12-20}}</ref> [[Mary Woronov]], known for her transgressive roles in cult films, eventually transitioned to mainstream films. She was expected to recreate the transgressive elements of her cult films within the confines of mainstream cinema. Instead of the complex gender deconstructions of her [[Andy Warhol]] films, she became typecast as a lesbian or domineering woman.<ref>{{cite web|last=Harris|first=Will|title=Cult Film Staple Mary Woronov on Andy Warhol, Roger Corman, and Being Typecast|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/cult-film-staple-mary-woronov-on-andy-warhol-roger-84658|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|accessdate=2013-06-05|date=2012-09-07}}</ref> [[Sylvia Kristel]], after starring in ''[[Emmanuelle (film)|Emmanuelle]]'' (1974), found herself highly associated with the film and the sexual liberation of the 1970s. Caught between the transgressive elements of her cult film and the mainstream appeal of soft-core pornography, she was unable to work in anything but exploitation films and ''Emmanuelle'' sequels. Despite her immense popularity and cult following, she would rate only a footnote in most histories of European cinema if she was even mentioned.<ref>{{cite book|last=Wimmer|first=Leila|title=Cult Film Stardom: Offbeat Attractions and Processes of Cultification|year=2012|publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]]|isbn=978-0-230-29369-4|page=197|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ygfq7T_r8jAC&pg=RA4-PT12|editor1-last=Egan|editor1-first=Kate|editor2-last=Thomas|editor2-first=Sarah|chapter=Chapter 11: Forever Emmanuelle: Sylvia Kristel and Soft-Core Cult Stardom|location=Houndsmills, Basingstoke, Hampshire New York}}</ref> Similarly, [[Chloë Sevigny]] has struggled with her reputation as a cult independent film star famous for her daring roles in transgressive films.<ref>{{cite book|last=Sexton|first=Jamie|editor1-last=Egan|editor1-first=Kate|editor2-last=Thomas|editor2-first=Sarah|title=Cult Film Stardom: Offbeat Attractions and Processes of Cultification|year=2012|publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]]|isbn=978-0-230-29369-4|pages=73–74|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x2hQSUYG7RQC&pg=PA73|chapter=Prisoner of Cool: Chloë Sevigny, Alternative Stardom and Image Management}}</ref> Cult films can also trap directors. [[Leonard Kastle]], who directed ''[[The Honeymoon Killers]]'' (1969), never directed another film again. Despite his cult following, which included [[François Truffaut]], he was unable to find financing for any of his other screenplays.<ref>{{cite news|last=Grimes|first=William|title=Leonard Kastle, Composer and Filmmaker, Dies at 82|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/22/arts/leonard-kastle-a-composer-who-directed-the-honeymoon-killers-dies-at-82.html|accessdate=2013-06-14|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=2011-05-21}}</ref> Qualities that bring cult films to prominence – such as an uncompromising, unorthodox vision – caused [[Alejandro Jodorowsky]] to languish in obscurity for years.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rose|first=Steve|title=Lennon, Manson and Me: the Psychedelic Cinema of Alejandro Jodorowsky|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/nov/14/alejandro-jodorowosky-el-topo|accessdate=2013-06-14|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=2009-11-13}}</ref>
==Transgression and censorship== [[File:Night of the Living Dead (1968) theatrical poster.jpg|thumb|alt=Theatrical poster of Night of the Living Dead|''[[Night of the Living Dead]]'' (1968) is an example of a cult film that uses transgressive themes.<ref>{{cite book|title=Cult Cinema|last1=Mathijs|first1=Ernest|last2=Sexton|first2=Jamie|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]|year=2012|isbn=978-1-4443-9642-3|page=101|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3EmSqIo4I-QC&pg=PA101|chapter=Transgression and Freakery}}</ref>]]
Transgressive films as a distinct artistic movement began in the 1970s. Unconcerned with genre distinctions, they drew inspiration equally from the nonconformity of [[European art cinema]] and [[experimental film]], the gritty subject matter of [[Italian neorealism]], and the shocking images of 1960s exploitation. Some used hardcore pornography and horror, occasionally at the same time. In the 1980s, filmmaker [[Nick Zedd]] identified this movement as the [[Cinema of Transgression]] and later wrote a manifesto. Popular in midnight showings, they were mainly limited to large urban areas, which led academic Joan Hawkins to label them as "downtown culture". These films acquired a legendary reputation as they were discussed and debated in alternative weeklies, such as ''[[The Village Voice]]''. Home video would finally allow general audiences to see them, which gave many people their first taste of underground film.<ref name=hawkins>{{cite book| last=Hawkins| first=Joan| title=Defining Cult Movies: the Cultural Politics of Oppositional Taste| year=2003| publisher=[[Manchester University Press]]| location=Manchester| isbn=978-0-7190-6631-3| editor1-last=Jancovich| editor1-first=Mark| editor2-last=Reboll| editor2-first=Antionio Lázaro| editor3-last=Stringer| editor3-first=Julian| editor4-last=Willis| editor4-first=Andy| chapter=Midnight Sex–Horror Movies}}</ref>{{rp|224–230}} Ernest Mathijs says that cult films often disrupt viewer expectations, such as giving characters transgressive motivations or focusing attention on elements outside the film.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hill |first=Mary Frances |title=Darkness rules for Batman fans in Vancouver |url=http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=375dc063-9e4f-41c6-bd1e-b653d6cb6314 |accessdate=2016-03-29 |newspaper=[[Vancouver Sun]] |date=2008-07-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416172113/http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=375dc063-9e4f-41c6-bd1e-b653d6cb6314 |archivedate=April 16, 2016 |df=mdy }}</ref> Cult films can also transgress national stereotypes and genre conventions, such as ''[[Battle Royale (film)|Battle Royale]]'' (2000), which broke many rules of teenage [[slasher film]]s.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Allsop|first=Samara L.|title=Battle Royale – Challenging Global Stereotypes Within the Constructs of a Contemporary Japanese Slasher Film|journal=The Film Journal|year=2002|issue=7|url=http://www.thefilmjournal.com/issue7/battleroyale.html|accessdate=2013-06-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130629195623/http://www.thefilmjournal.com/issue7/battleroyale.html|archivedate=June 29, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The reverse – when films based on cult properties lose their transgressive edge – can result in derision and rejection by fans.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Stadler|first=Jane|title=The Cult of Aeon Flux|journal=[[Flow (journal)|Flow]]|date=2007-09-29|volume=6|issue=7|url=http://flowtv.org/2007/09/cult-of-%C3%A6on-flux/|accessdate=2013-06-21}}</ref> Audience participation itself can be transgressive, such as breaking long-standing taboos against talking during films and throwing things at the screen.<ref name=spoons>{{cite journal| last=McCulloch| first=Richard| title='Most people bring their own spoons': The Room's Participatory Audiences as Comedy Mediators| journal=Participations| year=2011| volume=8| issue=2| url=http://www.participations.org/Volume%208/Issue%202/2d%20McCulloch.pdf| accessdate=2013-06-28}}</ref>{{rp|197}}
According to Mathijs, critical reception is important to a film's perception as cult, through topicality and controversy. Topicality, which can be regional (such as objection to government funding of the film) or critical (such as philosophical objections to the themes), enables attention and a contextual response. Cultural topics make the film relevant and can lead to controversy, such as a [[moral panic]], which provides opposition. Cultural values transgressed in the film, such as sexual promiscuity, can be attacked by proxy, through attacks on the film. These concerns can vary from culture to culture, and they need not be at all similar. However, Mathijs says the film must invoke metacommentary for it to be more than simply culturally important. While referencing previous arguments, critics may attack its choice of genre or its very right to exist. Taking stances on these varied issues, critics assure their own relevance while helping to elevate the film to cult status.<ref>{{cite book| last=Mathijs| first=Ernest| title=Defining Cult Movies: the Cultural Politics of Oppositional Taste| year=2003| publisher=[[Manchester University Press]]| location=Manchester| isbn=978-0-7190-6631-3| editor1-last=Jancovich| editor1-first=Mark| editor2-last=Reboll| editor2-first=Antionio Lázaro| editor3-last=Stringer| editor3-first=Julian| editor4-last=Willis| editor4-first=Andy| pages=109–123| chapter=The Making of a Cult Reputation}}</ref> Perceived racist and reductive remarks by critics can rally fans and raise the profile of cult films, an example of which would be Rex Reed's [[Rex Reed#Offensive comments in reviews|comments about Korean culture]] in his review of ''[[Oldboy (2003 film)|Oldboy]]'' (2003).<ref name=extreme /> Critics can also polarize audiences and lead debates, such as how Joe Bob Briggs and [[Roger Ebert]] dueled over ''[[I Spit On Your Grave]]'' (1978). Briggs would later contribute a commentary track to the DVD release in which he describes it as a feminist film.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Fidler|first=Tristan|editor1-last=Cash|editor1-first=Conall|editor2-last=Snow|editor2-first=Samuel Cuff|title="They Don't Call 'em Exploitation Movies for Nothing!": Joe Bob Briggs and the Critical Commentary on I Spit on Your Grave|journal=Colloquy|year=2009|issue=18|url=http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/colloquy/download/colloquy_issue_eighteen/fidler.pdf|accessdate=2013-06-23|publisher=[[Monash University]]}}</ref> Films which do not attract enough controversy may be ridiculed and rejected when suggested as cult films.<ref name=sick>{{cite journal|last=Church|first=David|title=Of Manias, Shit, and Blood: The Reception of Salò as a 'Sick Film'|journal=Participations|year=2009|volume=6|issue=2|url=http://www.participations.org/Volume%206/Issue%202/church.htm|accessdate=2013-07-06}}</ref>
Academic Peter Hutchings, noting the many definitions of a cult film that require transgressive elements, states that cult films are known in part for their excesses. Both subject matter and its depiction are portrayed in extreme ways that break taboos of good taste and aesthetic norms. Violence, gore, sexual perversity, and even the music can be pushed to stylistic excess far beyond that allowed by mainstream cinema. [[Film censorship]] can make these films obscure and difficult to find, common criteria used to define cult films. Despite this, these films remain well-known and prized among collectors. Fans will occasionally express frustration with dismissive critics and conventional analysis, which they believe marginalizes and misinterprets paracinema.<ref name=hutchings>{{cite book| last=Hutchings| first=Peter| title=Defining Cult Movies: the Cultural Politics of Oppositional Taste| year=2003| publisher=[[Manchester University Press]]| location=Manchester| isbn=978-0-7190-6631-3| editor1-last=Jancovich| editor1-first=Mark| editor2-last=Reboll| editor2-first=Antionio Lázaro| editor3-last=Stringer| editor3-first=Julian| editor4-last=Willis| editor4-first=Andy| chapter=The Argento Effect}}</ref>{{rp|131–134}} In marketing these films, young men are predominantly targeted.<ref name=extreme /> Horror films in particular can draw fans who seek the most extreme films.<ref name=sick /> Audiences can also ironically latch on to offensive themes, such as misogyny,<ref>{{cite news|last=Jupp|first=Emily|title=Terrible Acting, Flimsy Sets, Wanton Misogyny ... Tommy Wiseau's The Room Becomes a Cult Hit|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/features/terrible-acting-flimsy-sets-wanton-misogynytommy-wiseaus-the-room-becomes-a-cult-hit-8515346.html|accessdate=2013-05-19|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=2013-03-01}}</ref> using these films as catharsis for the things that they hate most in life.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ranade|first=Raj|title=A Really Bad Movie Becomes a Cult Classic|url=http://www.ctnow.com/entertainment/movies/nm-ht06filmtheroom-20130207,0,1433868.story|work=[[WTIC-TV]]|publisher=[[Tribune Broadcasting]]|accessdate=2014-11-22|date=2013-02-05}}</ref> Exploitative, transgressive elements can be pushed to excessive extremes for both humor and satire. [[Frank Henenlotter]] faced censorship and ridicule, but he found acceptance among audiences receptive to themes that Hollywood was reluctant to touch, such as violence, drug addiction, and misogyny.<ref>{{cite journal| last=Bett| first=Alan| title=Exploitation: An Interview with Frank Henenlotter| journal=[[The Skinny (magazine)|The Skinny]]| date=2013-05-10| url=http://www.theskinny.co.uk/film/features/304684-exploitation_interview_with_frank_henenlotter| accessdate=2013-06-15}}</ref> [[Lloyd Kaufman]] sees his films' political statements as more populist and authentic than the hypocrisy of mainstream films and celebrities. Despite featuring an abundance of fake blood, vomit, and diarrhea, Kaufman's films have attracted positive attention from critics and academics.<ref>{{cite web|last=O'Neal|first=Sean|title=Interview: Lloyd Kaufman|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/lloyd-kaufman-14238|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|accessdate=2013-06-15|date=2008-05-07}}</ref> Excess can also exist as camp, such as films that highlight the excesses of 1980s fashion and commercialism.<ref name=swayze>{{cite book|last=Batchelor|first=Bob|title=Cult Pop Culture: How the Fringe Became Mainstream: Volume 1|year=2011|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|isbn=978-0-313-35781-7|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jqd92sX1hAoC&pg=PA19|editor-first=Bob|editor-last=Batchelor|chapter=Swayze is America}}</ref>{{rp|19–20}}
Films that are influenced by unpopular styles or genres can become cult films. Director [[Jean Rollin]] worked within ''[[fantastique#Cinéma Fantastique|cinéma fantastique]]'', an unpopular genre in modern France. Influenced by American films and early French fantasists, he drifted between art, exploitation, and pornography. His films were reviled by critics, but he retained a cult following drawn by the nudity and eroticism.<ref>{{cite news| last=Kehr| first=Dave |title=Buxom, Lustful and Thirsty for Blood|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/29/movies/homevideo/five-cult-horror-films-by-jean-rollin-remastered-for-dvd.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2013-05-17|date=2012-01-27| authorlink=Dave Kehr}}</ref> Similarly, [[Jess Franco]] chafed under fascist censorship in Spain but became influential in Spain's horror boom of the 1960s.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Fitz-Gerald|first=Sean|title=Cult Filmmaker Jess Franco Dies at 82|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/jess-franco-1200332021/|accessdate=2013-05-17|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=2013-04-02}}</ref> These transgressive films that straddle the line between art and horror may have overlapping cult followings, each with their own interpretation and reasons for appreciating it.<ref name=sick /> The films that followed Jess Franco were unique in their rejection of mainstream art. Popular among fans of European horror for their subversiveness and obscurity, these later Spanish films allowed political dissidents to criticize the fascist regime within the cloak of exploitation and horror. Unlike most exploitation directors, they were not trying to establish a reputation. They were already established in the art-house world and intentionally chose to work within paracinema as a reaction against the [[Cinema of Spain#The new Spanish cinema|New Spanish Cinema]], an artistic revival supported by the fascists.<ref>{{cite book| last=Willis| first=Andy| title=Defining Cult Movies: the Cultural Politics of Oppositional Taste| year=2003| publisher=[[Manchester University Press]]| location=Manchester| isbn=978-0-7190-6631-3| editor1-last=Jancovich| editor1-first=Mark| editor2-last=Reboll| editor2-first=Antionio Lázaro| editor3-last=Stringer| editor3-first=Julian| editor4-last=Willis| editor4-first=Andy| pages=71–82| chapter=Spanish Horror and the Flight from Art Cinema}}</ref> As late as the 1980s, critics still cited [[Pedro Almodóvar]]'s anti-macho iconoclasm as a rebellion against fascist mores, as he grew from countercultural rebel to mainstream respectability.<ref>{{cite web|last=Levy|first=Emanuel|title=Almodovar: What Makes Pedro Run? Part Two|url=http://www.emanuellevy.com/comment/almodovar-what-makes-pedro-run-part-two/|work=EmanuelLevy.com|accessdate=2013-05-21|authorlink=Emanuel Levy}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Elgrably|first=Jordan|title=Directors Anti-Macho Man|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-01-19/magazine/tm-539_1_director-pedro-almodovar|accessdate=2013-05-21|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=1992-01-19}}</ref> Transgressive elements that limit a director's appeal in one country can be celebrated or highlighted in another. [[Takashi Miike]] has been marketed in the West as a shocking and avant-garde filmmaker despite his many family-friendly comedies, which have not been imported.<ref name=extreme />
The transgressive nature of cult films can lead to their censorship. During the 1970s and early 1980s, a wave of explicit, graphic exploitation films caused controversy. Called "[[video nasty|video nasties]]" within the UK, they ignited calls for censorship and stricter laws on home video releases, which were largely unregulated.<ref>{{cite news|last=Holmes|first=Andrew|title=Let There Be Blood|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2002/jul/05/filmcensorship.artsfeatures|accessdate=2013-06-08|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=2002-07-04}}</ref> Consequently, the [[British Board of Film Classification]] banned many popular cult films due to issues of sex, violence, and incitement to crime.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kemp|first=Stuart|title=BFI to Screen Uncut Versions of Cult Films as British Censor Turns 100|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/bfi-to-show-uncut-films-to-celebrate100-years-of-british-censor-378560|accessdate=2013-05-14|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=2012-12-10}}</ref> Released during the [[cannibal boom]], ''[[Cannibal Holocaust]]'' (1980) was banned in dozens of countries and caused the director to be briefly jailed over fears that it was a real [[snuff film]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=McNary|first=Dave|title=Relevant Nabs 'Cannibal'|journal=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=2007-02-01|url=https://variety.com/2007/film/news/relevant-nabs-cannibal-1117958508/|accessdate=2013-06-08}}</ref> Although opposed to censorship, director [[Ruggero Deodato]] would later agree with cuts made by the BBFC which removed unsimulated animal killings, which limited the film's distribution.<ref>{{cite news|last=Masters|first=Tim|title='Video Nasty' Director Deodato Debates Censorship|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-13550879|accessdate=2013-06-15|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|date=2011-05-26}}</ref> Frequently banned films may introduce questions of authenticity as fans question whether they have seen a truly uncensored cut.<ref name=sick /> Cult films have been falsely claimed to have been banned to increase their transgressive reputation and explain their lack of mainstream penetration. Marketing campaigns have also used such claims to raise interest among curious audiences.<ref>{{cite news|last=Erickson|first=Steve|title=How 'Battle Royale' Became a Cult Hit and Capitalized on 'The Hunger Games'|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2012/03/how-battle-royale-became-a-cult-hit-and-capitalized-on-the-hunger-games/254184/|accessdate=2013-05-14|newspaper=[[The Atlantic]]|date=2012-03-20}}</ref> Home video has allowed cult film fans to import rare or banned films, finally giving them a chance to complete their collection with imports and bootlegs. Cult films previously banned are sometimes released with much fanfare and the fans assumed to be already familiar with the controversy. Personal responsibility is often highlighted, and a strong anti-censorship message may be present.<ref name=hutchings />{{rp|130–132}} Previously lost scenes cut by studios can be re-added and restore a director's original vision, which draws similar fanfare and acclaim from fans.<ref>{{cite news|title=Russell's Skills Prove a Hit with Cinema Fans|url=http://www.ilkestonadvertiser.co.uk/what-s-on/out-about/russell-s-skills-prove-a-hit-with-cinema-fans-1-5778145|accessdate=2013-06-24|newspaper=Ilkeston Advertiser|date=2013-06-24}}</ref> Imports are sometimes censored to remove elements that would be controversial, such as references to Islamic spirituality in Indonesian cult films.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Imanjaya|first=Ekky|editor1-last=Cash|editor1-first=Conall|editor2-last=Snow|editor2-first=Samuel Cuff|title=The Other Side of Indonesia: New Order's Indonesian Exploitation Cinema as Cult Films|journal=Colloquy|year=2009|issue=18|url=http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/colloquy/download/colloquy_issue_eighteen/iminjaya.pdf|accessdate=2013-06-23|publisher=[[Monash University]]}}</ref>
Academics have written of how transgressive themes in cult films can be regressive. David Church and Chuck Kleinhans describe an uncritical celebration of transgressive themes in cult films, including misogyny and racism.<ref name=cineaste /> Church has also criticized gendered descriptions of transgressive content that celebrate masculinity.<ref name=sick /> Joanne Hollows further identifies a gendered component to the celebration of transgressive themes in cult films, where male terms are used to describe films outside the mainstream while female terms are used to describe mainstream, conformist cinema.<ref name=hollows />{{rp|35–40}} Jacinda Read's expansion states that cult films, despite their potential for empowerment of the marginalized, are more often used by politically incorrect males. Knowledgeable about feminism and multiculturalism, they seek a refuge from the academic acceptance of these progressive ideals. Their playful and ironic acceptance of regressive [[lad culture]] invites, and even dares, condemnation from academics and the uncool. Thus, cult films become a tool to reinforce mainstream values through transgressive content;<ref>{{cite book| last=Read| first=Jacinda| title=Defining Cult Movies: the Cultural Politics of Oppositional Taste| year=2003| publisher=[[Manchester University Press]]| location=Manchester| isbn=978-0-7190-6631-3| editor1-last=Jancovich| editor1-first=Mark| editor2-last=Reboll| editor2-first=Antionio Lázaro| editor3-last=Stringer| editor3-first=Julian| editor4-last=Willis| editor4-first=Andy| pages=59–68| chapter=The Cult of Masculinity}}</ref> Rebecca Feasy states that cultural hierarchies can also be reaffirmed through mockery of films perceived to be lacking masculinity.<ref>{{cite book| last=Feasy| first=Rebecca| chapter=Sharon Stone, Screen Diva| title=Defining Cult Movies: The Cultural Politics of Oppositional Taste| editor1-last=Jancovich| editor1-first=Mark| editor2-last=Reboll| editor2-first=Antionio Lázaro| editor3-last=Stringer| editor3-first=Julian| editor4-last=Willis| editor4-first=Andy| year=2003| publisher=University of Manchester Press| location=Manchester| isbn=978-0-7190-6631-3| pages=172–174, 182}}</ref> However, the [[sexploitation]] films of [[Doris Wishman]] took a feminist approach which avoids and subverts the [[male gaze]] and traditional goal-oriented methods. Wishman's subject matter, though exploitative and transgressive, was always framed in terms of female empowerment and the feminine spectator. Her use of common cult film motifs – female nudity and ambiguous gender – were repurposed to comment on feminist topics.<ref>{{cite book| last=Luckett| first=Moya| title=Defining Cult Movies: the Cultural Politics of Oppositional Taste| year=2003| publisher=[[Manchester University Press]]| location=Manchester| isbn=978-0-7190-6631-3| editor1-last=Jancovich| editor1-first=Mark| editor2-last=Reboll| editor2-first=Antionio Lázaro| editor3-last=Stringer| editor3-first=Julian| editor4-last=Willis| editor4-first=Andy| pages=142–154| chapter=Sexploitation as Feminine Territory}}</ref> Similarly, the films of [[Russ Meyer]] were a complicated combination of transgressive, mainstream, progressive, and regressive elements. They attracted both acclaim and denouncement from critics and progressives.<ref name=meyer>{{cite book|last=Capitanio|first=Adam G.|title=Cult Pop Culture: How the Fringe Became Mainstream: How the Fringe Became Mainstream, Volume 1|year=2011|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|isbn=978-0-313-35781-7|pages=3–15|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jqd92sX1hAoC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA3|editor=Bob Batchelor|chapter=Sexploitation Cinema and the Rise and Fall of Russ Meyer}}</ref> Transgressive films imported from cultures that are recognizably different yet still relatable can be used to progressively examine issues in another culture.<ref>{{cite book|last=Selfe|first=Melanie|editor1-first=Lucy|editor1-last=Mazdon|editor2-first=Catherine|editor2-last=Wheatley|title=Je T'Aime, Moi Non Plus: Franco-British Cinematic Relations|year=2010|publisher=Berghahn Books|location=New York|isbn=978-1-84545-855-3|pages=164–165|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N0LmrUFWBl4C&pg=PA164|accessdate=2013-06-25|chapter=Incredibly French}}</ref>
==Subcultural appeal and fandom== Cult films can be used to help define or create groups as a form of [[subcultural capital]]; knowledge of cult films proves that one is "authentic" or "non-mainstream". They can be used to provoke an outraged response from the mainstream, which further defines the subculture, as only members could possibly tolerate such deviant entertainment.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mathijs|first1=Ernest|last2=Sexton|first2=Jamie|title=Cult Cinema|year=2011|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]|isbn=978-1-4051-7374-2|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ntg-1SAKgboC&pg=PA61|chapter=Fandom and Subculture: Cultural Capital and Subcultures|page=61|location=Chichester, West Sussex Malden, MA}}</ref> More accessible films have less subcultural capital;<ref name=alamo /> among extremists, banned films will have the most.<ref name=sick /> By referencing cult films, media can identify desired demographics, strengthen bonds with specific subcultures, and stand out among those who understand the [[intertextuality]].<ref name=borrowings>{{cite book|last=Cherry|first=Brigid|title=Cultural Borrowings: Appropriation, Reworking, Transformation|chapter=From Cult to Subculture: Reimaginings of Cult Films in Alternative Music Video|url=http://www.scope.nottingham.ac.uk/cultborr/chapter.php?id=11|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004042250/http://www.scope.nottingham.ac.uk/cultborr/chapter.php?id=11|archivedate=2011-10-04|accessdate=2013-05-22|editor-last=Smith|editor-first=Iain Robert|publisher=[[University of Nottingham]]|isbn=978-0-9564641-0-1|year=2009}}</ref> Popular films from previous eras may be reclaimed by genre fans long after they have been forgotten by the original audiences. This can be done for authenticity, such as horror fans who seek out now-obscure titles from the 1950s instead of the modern, well-known remakes.<ref>{{cite book|last=Paszylk|first=Bartłomiej|title=The Pleasure and Pain of Cult Horror Films: An Historical Survey|year=2009|publisher=[[McFarland & Co.]]|location=Jefferson, N.C.|isbn=978-0-7864-5327-6|page=3|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SWCx_jpxkdwC&pg=PA3|chapter=Introduction}}</ref> Authenticity may also drive fans to deny genre categorization to films perceived as too mainstream or accessible.<ref name=genre>{{cite book|last=Hills|first=Matt|title=The SAGE Handbook of Film Studies|year=2008|publisher=[[Sage Publications]]|isbn=978-1-4462-0682-9|chapter=The Question of Genre in Cult Film and Fandom|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A9NX-vJqFy8C&pg=PA436}}</ref>{{rp|439}} Authenticity in performance<ref name=hunt />{{rp|157–168}} and expertise<ref name=trivia />{{rp|196}} can drive fan acclaim. Authenticity can also drive fans to decry the mainstream in the form of hostile critics and censors.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Egan|first=Kate|title=The Amateur Historian and the Electronic Archive: Identity, Power and the Function of Lists, Facts and Memories on "Video Nasty"-Themed Websites|journal=Intensities|year=2003|issue=3|url=http://intensitiescultmedia.files.wordpress.com/2012/12/egan-the-amateur-historian-and-the-electronic-archive.pdf|accessdate=2013-06-25|editor1-first=Matt|editor1-last=Hills|editor2-first=Sara Gwenllian|editor2-last=Jones}}</ref> Especially when promoted by enthusiastic and knowledgeable programmers, choice of venue can be an important part of expressing individuality.<ref name=alamo /> Besides creating new communities, cult films can link formerly disparate groups, such as fans and critics.<ref name=hutchings />{{rp|127}} As these groups intermix, they can influence each other, though this may be resisted by older fans, unfamiliar with these new references.<ref name=hunt />{{rp|164}} In extreme cases, cult films can lead to the creation of religions, such as [[Dudeism]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Ashley|last=Fetters|title=Still Abiding After 15 Years: The Laid-Back World of 'Big Lebowski' Worship|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2013/03/still-abiding-after-15-years-the-laid-back-world-of-big-lebowski-worship/273750/|accessdate=2013-05-13|newspaper=[[The Atlantic]]|date=2013-03-06}}</ref> For their avoidance of mainstream culture and audiences, enjoyment of irony, and celebration of obscure subcultures, academic Martin Roberts compares cult film fans to [[Hipster (contemporary subculture)|hipsters]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Roberts|first=Martin|title="I'm Riding a Panda!": Japanese Cult Media and Hipster Cosmopolitanism|journal=[[Flow (journal)|Flow]]|date=2009-04-02|volume=9|issue=10|url=http://flowtv.org/2009/04/im-riding-a-panda-japanese-cult-media-and-hipster-cosmopolitanism-martin-roberts-the-new-school/|accessdate=2013-06-19}}</ref>
[[File:The Wizard of Oz Judy Garland 1939.jpg|thumb|alt=A black and white still of Judy Garland from The Wizard of Oz|Judy Garland and her iconic role as Dorothy Gale have become important in [[LGBT culture|gay culture]].]]
A film can become the object of a cult following within a particular region or culture if it has unusual significance.<ref name="not-cult" /> For example, [[Norman Wisdom]]'s films, friendly to Marxist interpretation, amassed a cult following in Albania, as they were among the few Western films allowed by the country's Communist rulers.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/culture-obituaries/film-obituaries/8042823/Sir-Norman-Wisdom.html|title=Sir Norman Wisdom|date=2010-10-05|accessdate=2010-10-06|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|Telegraph]] | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/newsnight/9063102.stm|title=Norman Wisdom Mobbed by Albanian Fans on 1995 Trip|date=2010-10-05|work=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=2010-10-11}}</ref> ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'' (1939) and its star, [[Judy Garland]], hold [[Judy Garland as gay icon|special significance]] to American and British gay culture, although it is a widely viewed and historically important film in greater American culture. Similarly, [[James Dean]] and his brief film career have become icons of alienated youth.<ref>{{cite book|last=Wilson|first=Kristi M.|title=Cult Pop Culture: How the Fringe Became Mainstream|year=2011|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|isbn=978-0-313-35780-0|pages=61–63|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lAIMzLLh9nUC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA61|editor-first=Bob|editor-last=Batchelor|chapter=Demogogues in Death and Notes from Way Underground}}</ref> Cult films can have such niche appeal that they are only popular within certain subcultures, such as ''[[Reefer Madness]]'' (1936)<ref>{{cite book |last=Peary |first=Danny |title=[[Cult Movies (book)|Cult Movies]] |year=1981 |publisher=[[Delacorte Press]] |location=New York |isbn=0-440-01626-6 |pages=203–205| authorlink=Danny Peary}}</ref> and ''[[Hemp for Victory]]'' (1942)<ref>{{cite news|last=Kelly|first=Jon|title=Hemp: Could the US Rekindle Its Love Affair?|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-20463504|accessdate=2013-05-06|newspaper=[[BBC News Magazine]]|date=2012-11-25}}</ref> among the [[Cannabis culture|stoner subculture]]. Beach party musicals, popular among American surfers, failed to find an equivalent audience when imported to the United Kingdom. When films target subcultures like this, they may seem unintelligible without the proper [[cultural capital]]. Films which appeal to teenagers may offer subcultural identities that are easily recognized and differentiate various subcultural groups.<ref name=beach>{{cite journal|last=Caine|first=Andrew|title=The A.I.P. Beach Movies - Cult Films Depicting Subcultural Activities|journal=Scope|year=2001|issue=Dec 2001|url=http://www.scope.nottingham.ac.uk/article.php?issue=dec2001&id=277&section=article|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130623041915/http://www.scope.nottingham.ac.uk/article.php?issue=dec2001&id=277&section=article|archivedate=2013-06-23|accessdate=2013-05-19|issn=1465-9166|publisher=[[University of Nottingham]]}}</ref> Films which appeal to stereotypical male activities, such as sports, can easily gain strong male cult followings.<ref name=swayze /> Sports metaphors are often used in the marketing of cult films to males, such as emphasizing the "extreme" nature of the film, which increases the appeal to youth subcultures fond of extreme sports.<ref name=extreme />
{{anchor|cult blockbuster}} Matt Hills' concept of the "cult blockbuster" involves cult followings inside larger, mainstream films. Although these are big budget, mainstream films, they still attract cult followings. The cult fans differentiate themselves from ordinary fans in several ways: longstanding devotion to the film, distinctive interpretations, and [[fan work]]s. Hills identifies three different cult followings for ''[[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|The Lord of the Rings]]'', each with their own fandom separate from the mainstream.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hills|first=Matt|title=The Lord of the Rings: Popular Culture in Global Context|year=2006|publisher=Wallflower Press|location=London New York|isbn=978-1-904764-82-3|pages=160–169|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I8mxughWAOEC&pg=PA160|editor-first=Ernest|editor-last=Mathijs|chapter=Realising the Cult Blockbuster: The Lord of the Rings Fandom and Residual/Emergent Cult Status in 'The Mainstream'}}</ref> Academic Emma Pett identifies ''[[Back to the Future]]'' (1985) as another example of a cult blockbuster. Although the film topped the charts when it was released, it has developed a nostalgic cult following over the years. The hammy acting by [[Christopher Lloyd]] and quotable dialogue draw a cult following, as they mimic traditional cult films.<ref name=nostalgia>{{cite journal|last=Pett|first=Emma|title='Hey! Hey! I've seen this one, I've seen this one. It's a classic': Nostalgia, Repeat Viewing and Cult Performance in Back to the Future|journal=Participations|year=2013|volume=10|issue=1|url=http://www.participations.org/Volume%2010/Issue%201/11%20Pett%2010.1.pdf|accessdate=2013-07-01}}</ref> Blockbuster science fiction films that include philosophical subtexts, such as ''[[The Matrix (franchise)|The Matrix]]'', allow cult film fans to enjoy them on a higher level than the mainstream.<ref name=genre />{{rp|445}} ''[[Star Wars]]'', with its large cult following in geek subculture, has been cited as both a cult blockbuster<ref>{{cite book|last=Scott|first=Jason|title=Cult Film Stardom: Offbeat Attractions and Processes of Cultification|year=2012|publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]]|isbn=978-0-230-29369-4|pages=91–94|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h7xn-AWOj88C&pg=PA91|editor1-last=Egan|editor1-first=Kate|editor2-last=Thomas|editor2-first=Sarah|chapter=Chapter 5: From Behind the Masks to Inside: Acting, Authenticity, and the ''Star Wars'' Co-Stars|location=Houndsmills, Basingstoke, Hampshire New York}}</ref> and a cult film.<ref name=cineaste /> Although a mainstream epic, ''Star Wars'' has provided its fans with a spirituality and culture outside of the mainstream.<ref>{{cite book| last1=Mathijs| first1=Ernest| last2=Sexton| first2=Jamie| title=Cult Cinema| year=2011| publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]| isbn=978-1-4051-7374-2| page=64| chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ntg-1SAKgboC&pg=PA64| accessdate=2013-05-23| chapter=Fandom and Subculture: Mainstream Cult Fans?|location=Chichester, West Sussex Malden, MA}}</ref> Fans, in response to the popularity of these blockbusters, will claim elements for themselves while rejecting others. For example, in the ''Star Wars'' film series, mainstream [[Jar Jar Binks#Allegations of racial caricature|criticism of Jar Jar Binks]] focused on racial stereotyping; although cult film fans will use that to bolster their arguments, he is rejected because he represents mainstream appeal and marketing.<ref name=trivia>{{cite book|last=Hunt|first=Nathan|chapter=The Importance of Trivia|title=Defining Cult Movies: The Cultural Politics of Oppositional Taste|editor1-last=Jancovich|editor1-first=Mark|editor2-last=Reboll|editor2-first=Antionio Lázaro|editor3-last=Stringer|editor3-first=Julian|editor4-last=Willis|editor4-first=Andy|year=2003|publisher=University of Manchester Press|location=Manchester|isbn=978-0-7190-6631-3}}</ref>{{rp|190–193}} Also, instead of valuing textual rarity, fans of cult blockbusters will value repeat viewings. They may also engage in behaviors more traditional for fans of cult television and other serial media, as cult blockbusters are often franchised, preconceived as a film series, or both.<ref name=pearson /> To reduce mainstream accessibility, a film series can be self-reflexive and full of in-jokes that only longtime fans can understand.<ref name=beach />
Cult films can create their own subculture. ''Rocky Horror'', originally made to exploit the popularity of [[glam rock|glam subculture]], became what academic Gina Marchetti called a "sub-subculture", a variant that outlived its parent subculture.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Cult Film Reader|last=Marchetti|first=Gina|page=413|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dWX4AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA412|chapter=Subcultural Studies and the Film Audience|editor1-last=Mathijs|editor1-first=Ernest|editor2-last=Mendik|editor2-first=Xavier|publisher=[[McGraw-Hill International]]|year=2007|isbn=978-0-335-21923-0}}</ref> Although often described as primarily composed of obsessed fans, cult film fandom can include many newer, less experienced members.<ref name=spoons />{{rp|190–191}} Familiar with the film's reputation and having watched clips on YouTube, these fans may take the next step and enter the film's fandom. If they are the majority, they may alter or ignore long-standing traditions, such as audience participation rituals; rituals which lack perceived authenticity may be criticized, but accepted rituals bring subcultural capital to veteran fans who introduce them to the newer members. Fans who flaunt their knowledge receive negative reactions. Newer fans may cite the film itself as their reason for attending a showing, but longtime fans often cite the community. Organized fandoms may spread and become popular as a way of introducing new people to the film, as well as theatrical screenings being privileged by the media and fandom itself. Fandom can also be used as a process of legitimation.<ref name=spoons />{{rp|200–211}} Fans of cult films, as in [[media fandom]], are frequently producers instead of mere consumers. Unconcerned with traditional views on intellectual property, these fan works are often unsanctioned, transformative, and ignore [[Canon (fiction)|fictional canon]].<ref>{{cite book| last1=Mathijs| first1=Ernest| last2=Sexton| first2=Jamie| title=Cult Cinema| year=2011| publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]| isbn=978-1-4051-7374-2| page=57|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ntg-1SAKgboC&pg=PA57| chapter=Fandom and Subculture: Fan Studies: Early Approaches| location=Chichester, West Sussex Malden, MA}}</ref>
Like cult films themselves, magazines and websites dedicated to cult films revel in their self-conscious offensiveness. They maintain a sense of exclusivity by offending mainstream audiences with misogyny, gore, and racism. Obsessive trivia can be used to bore mainstream audiences while building up subcultural capital. Specialist stores on the fringes of society (or websites which prominently partner with hardcore pornographic sites) can be used to reinforce the outsider nature of cult film fandom, especially when they use erotic or gory imagery.<ref name=hollows />{{rp|45–47}} By assuming a preexisting knowledge of trivia, non-fans can be excluded. Previous articles and controversies can also be alluded to without explanation. Casual readers and non-fans will thus be left out of discussions and debates, as they lack enough information to meaningfully contribute. When fans like a cult film for the wrong reasons, such as casting or characters aimed at mainstream appeal, they may be ridiculed. Thus, fandom can keep the mainstream at bay while defining themselves in terms of the "[[Other (philosophy)|Other]]", a philosophical construct divergent from [[Norm (social)|social norms]]. Commercial aspects of fandom (such as magazines or books) can also be defined in terms of "otherness" and thus valid to consume: consumers purchasing independent or niche publications are discerning consumers, but the mainstream is denigrated. Irony or self-deprecating humor can also be used.<ref name=trivia />{{rp|192–197}} In online communities, different subcultures attracted to transgressive films can clash over values and criteria for subcultural capital. Even within subcultures, fans who break subcultural scripts, such as denying the affectivity of a disturbing film, will be ridiculed for their lack of authenticity.<ref name=sick />
==Types== ==="So bad it's good"=== {{See also|Z movie}} The critic [[Michael Medved]] characterized examples of the "so bad it's good" class of low-budget cult film through books such as ''[[The Golden Turkey Awards]]''. These films include financially fruitless and critically scorned films that have become inadvertent comedies to film buffs, such as ''[[Plan 9 from Outer Space]]'' (1959)<ref name=plan9>{{cite news|last=Palopoli|first=Steve|title=Cult Leader: "Plan 9 from Outer Space"|url=http://www.metroactive.com/metro/05.31.06/cult-0622.html|accessdate=2013-05-03|newspaper=[[Metro Silicon Valley]]|date=2006-05-31}}</ref> and ''[[The Room (film)|The Room]]'' (2003).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Collis|first=Clark|title=The Crazy Cult of "The Room"|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20246031,00.html|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=2013-05-03|date=2008-12-12|issue=1026}}</ref> Similarly, [[Paul Verhoeven]]'s ''[[Showgirls]]'' (1995) bombed in theaters but developed a cult following on video. Catching on, [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] capitalized on the film's ironic appeal and marketed it as a cult film.<ref>{{cite web|last=Heitmueller|first=Karl|title=Rewind: Major-Studio Flicks That Belong In The Grind House|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1556111/rewind-major-studio-flicks-that-belong-in-the-grind-house/|work=[[MTV]]|accessdate=2013-05-04|date=2007-04-03}}</ref> Sometimes fans will impose their own interpretation of films which have attracted derision, such as reinterpreting an earnest melodrama as a comedy.<ref name=spoons />{{rp|212}} Jacob deNobel of the ''[[Carroll County Times]]'' states that films can be perceived as nonsensical or inept when audiences misunderstand avant-garde filmmaking or misinterpret parody. Films such as ''Rocky Horror'' can be misinterpreted as "weird for weirdness' sake" by people unfamiliar with the cult films that it parodies. deNobel ultimately rejects the use of the label "so bad it's good" as mean-spirited and often misapplied.<ref>{{cite news|last=deNobel |first=Jacob |title=Good Bad Taste: 'Rocky Horror Picture Show' and the So Bad It's Good Fallacy |url=http://localbiz.carrollcountytimes.com/community_times/blogs/goodbadtaste/good-bad-taste-rocky-horror-picture-show-and-the-so/article_58a28700-b2fe-50bf-9890-8429a2c6a9a5.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20141122174800/http://localbiz.carrollcountytimes.com/community_times/blogs/goodbadtaste/good-bad-taste-rocky-horror-picture-show-and-the-so/article_58a28700-b2fe-50bf-9890-8429a2c6a9a5.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-11-22 |accessdate=2013-05-28 |newspaper=[[Carroll County Times]] |date=2013-05-26 }}</ref> Alamo Drafthouse programmer Zack Carlson has further said that any film which succeeds in entertaining an audience is good, regardless of irony.<ref>{{cite web|last=Carlson|first=Zack|title=Miami Connection Destroys the Myth of 'So Bad They're Good' Movies|url=https://www.wired.com/2012/10/opinion-miami-connection/all/|work=[[Wired (website)|Wired]]|accessdate=2013-05-19|date=2012-10-25}}</ref> The rise of the Internet and on-demand films has led critics to question whether "so bad it's good" films have a future now that people have such diverse options in both availability and catalog,<ref>{{cite news|last=Doerksen|first=Cliff|title="So Bad It's Good" Isn't All That Bad|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/Bleader/archives/2010/08/02/so-bad-its-good-isnt-all-that-bad|accessdate=2013-05-19|newspaper=[[Chicago Reader]]|date=2010-08-02}}</ref> though fans eager to experience the worst films ever made can lead to lucrative showings for local theaters<ref>{{cite news|last=Anderman|first=Joan|title=Cult film Is Good Business at Coolidge Corner Theatre|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/movies/articles/2010/06/19/cult_film_is_good_business_at_coolidge_corner_theatre/|accessdate=2013-05-31|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=2010-06-19}}</ref> and merchandisers.<ref>{{cite news|last=Patel|first=Nihar|title='The Room': A Cult Hit So Bad, It's Good|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5384997|accessdate=2013-06-16|newspaper=[[National Public Radio]]|date=2006-05-05}}</ref>
===Camp and guilty pleasures=== Chuck Kleinhans states that the difference between a guilty pleasure and a cult film can be as simple as the number of fans; David Church raises the question of how many people it takes to form a cult following, especially now that home video makes fans difficult to count.<ref name=cineaste /> As these cult films become more popular, they can bring varied responses from fans that depend on different interpretations, such as [[camp (style)|camp]], irony, genuine affection, or combinations thereof. Earnest fans, who recognize and accept the film's faults, can make minor celebrities of the film's cast,<ref>{{cite web|last=Adams|first=Sam|title="Best Worst Movie": The Cult of the Truly Bad Film|url=http://www.salon.com/2010/05/14/best_worst_movie/|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|accessdate=2013-06-16|date=2010-05-14}}</ref> though the benefits are not always clear.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Paris|first=Robyn|title=How 'The Room' Turned Me Into a Cult Movie 'Star'|journal=[[Backstage (magazine)|Backstage]]|date=2012-04-30|url=http://www.backstage.com/advice-for-actors/first-person/how-the-room-turned-me-into-a-cult-movie-star/|accessdate=2013-06-16}}</ref> Cult film stars known for their camp can inject subtle parody or signal when films should not be taken seriously.<ref>{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Justin|editor1-first=Kate|editor1-last=Egan|editor2-first=Sarah|editor2-last=Thomas|title=Cult Film Stardom: Offbeat Attractions and Processes of Cultification|year=2012|publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]]|isbn=978-0-230-29369-4|pages=110–111|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h7xn-AWOj88C&pg=PA110|chapter=Vincent Price and Cult Performance: the Case of Witchfinder General}}</ref> Campy actors can also provide comic book supervillains for serious, artistic-minded films. This can draw fan acclaim and obsession more readily than subtle, [[method acting|method]]-inspired acting.<ref>{{cite book|last=Simpson|first=Philip L.|title=Cult Pop Culture: How the Fringe Became Mainstream|year=2011|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|isbn=978-0-313-35780-0|pages=90–91|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lAIMzLLh9nUC&pg=PA90|editor-first=Bob|editor-last=Batchelor|chapter=Lector for President}}</ref> Mark Chalon Smith of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' says technical faults may be forgiven if a film makes up for them in other areas, such as camp or transgressive content. Smith states that the early films of [[John Waters (director born 1946)|John Waters]] are amateurish and less influential than claimed, but Waters' outrageous vision cements his place in cult cinema.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Mark Chalon|title=FILM: 'Pink Flamingos': Cult of Bad Taste|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-04-02/news/ol-91_1_pink-flamingos|accessdate=2013-06-16|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=1992-04-02}}</ref> Films such as ''[[Myra Breckinridge (film)|Myra Breckinridge]]'' (1970) and ''[[Beyond the Valley of the Dolls]]'' (1970) can experience critical reappraisal later, once their camp excess and avant-garde filmmaking are better accepted,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Diffrient|first=David Scott|title="Hard to Handle": Camp Criticism, Trash-Film Reception, and the Transgressive Pleasures of Myra Breckinridge|journal=[[Cinema Journal]]|year=2013|volume=52|issue=2|url=http://muse.jhu.edu/login?auth=0&type=summary&url=/journals/cinema_journal/v052/52.2.diffrient.pdf|accessdate=2013-06-29|subscription=yes|via=[[Project MUSE]]}}</ref> and films that are initially dismissed as frivolous are often reassessed as campy.<ref name=beach /> Films that intentionally try to appeal to fans of camp may end up alienating them, as the films become perceived as trying too hard or not authentic.<ref>{{cite book|last=Jackson|first=Jeffrey C.|title=Cult Pop Culture: How the Fringe Became Mainstream|year=2011|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|isbn=978-0-313-35780-0|page=48|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lAIMzLLh9nUC&pg=PA48|editor-last=Batchelor|editor-first=Bob|chapter=The Godfather of Cult}}</ref>
===Nostalgia=== According to academic Brigid Cherry, [[nostalgia]] "is a strong element of certain kinds of cult appeal."<ref name=borrowings /> When [[Veoh]] added many cult films to their site, they cited nostalgia as a factor for their popularity.<ref>{{cite web|last=Termen|first=Amanda|title=It's the Site of the Living Dead, as Cult Films Hit Web|url=http://news.cnet.com/2100-1025_3-6047466.html|work=[[CNET]]|accessdate=2013-08-01|date=2006-03-08}}</ref> Academic I. Q. Hunter describes cult films as "New Hollywood ''in extremis''" and a form of nostalgia for that period. Ernest Mathijs instead states that cult films use nostalgia as a form of resistance against progress and capitalistic ideas of a time-based economy.<ref name=cineaste /> By virtue of the time travel plot, ''Back to the Future'' permits nostalgia for both the 1950s and 1980s. Many members of its nostalgic cult following are too young to have been alive during those periods, which Emma Pett interprets as fondness for retro aesthetics, nostalgia for when they saw the film rather than when it was released, and looking to the past to find a better time period.<ref name=nostalgia /> Similarly, films directed by [[John Hughes (filmmaker)|John Hughes]] have taken hold in midnight movie venues, trading off of nostalgia for the 1980s and an ironic appreciation for their optimism.<ref>{{cite news|last=Beale|first=Lewis|title=John Hughes Versus the Vampires: The Dilemma of the Midnight Movie|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/06/19/movies/19beal.html|accessdate=2013-08-01|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=2006-06-19}}</ref> Mathijs and Sexton describe ''[[Grease (film)|Grease]]'' (1978) as a film nostalgic about an imagined past that has acquired a nostalgic cult following. Other cult films, such as ''[[Streets of Fire]]'' (1984), create a new fictional world based on nostalgic views of the past.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mathijs|first1=Ernest|last2=Sexton|first2=Jamie|title=Cult Cinema|year=2011|publisher=[[Wiley & Sons]]|isbn=978-1-4443-9643-0|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uPtuaV7IAt0C&pg=PT217|accessdate=2013-08-01|chapter=Cult Cinema and Music}}</ref> Cult films may also subvert nostalgia, such as ''The Big Lebowski'', which introduces many nostalgic elements and then reveals them as fake and hollow.<ref>{{cite news|last=Boudreau|first=Emily|title=The History and Meaning of The Dude's Abiding|url=http://www.michigandaily.com/content/big-lebowski-retrospective-notebook|accessdate=2013-08-01|newspaper=[[Michigan Daily]]|date=2010-09-08}}</ref> Nathan Lee of the ''[[New York Sun]]'' identifies the retro aesthetic and nostalgic pastiche in films such as ''[[Donnie Darko]]'' as factors in its popularity among midnight movie crowds.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lee|first=Nathan|title=How 'Donnie Darko' Refused to Die|url=http://www.nysun.com/arts/how-donnie-darko-refused-to-die/134/|accessdate=2013-08-01|newspaper=[[New York Sun]]|date=2004-07-25}}</ref>
===Midnight movies=== Author Tomas Crowder-Taraborrelli describes [[midnight movie]]s as a reaction against the political and cultural conservatism in America,<ref name=midnight />{{rp|27}} and Joan Hawkins identifies the movement as running the gamut from anarchist to [[Libertarianism|libertarian]], united in their anti-establishment attitude and punk aesthetic.<ref name=hawkins />{{rp|223}} These films are resistant to simple categorization and are defined by the fanaticism and ritualistic behaviors of their audiences. Midnight movies require a night life and an audience willing to invest themselves actively.<ref name=midnight>{{cite book|last=Crowder-Taraborrelli|first=Tomas F.|title=Cult Pop Culture: How the Fringe Became Mainstream: How the Fringe Became Mainstream, Volume 1|year=2011|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|isbn=978-0-313-35781-7|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jqd92sX1hAoC&pg=PA27|editor-first=Bob|editor-last=Batchelor|chapter=Midnight Movies and the Phenomenon of the Cult Film}}</ref>{{rp|27–30}} Hawkins states that these films took a rather bleak point of view due to the living conditions of the artists and the economic prospects of the 1970s. Like the surrealists and dadaists, they not only satirically attacked society but also the very structure of film – a counter-cinema that deconstructs narrative and traditional processes.<ref name=hawkins />{{rp|224–226}} In the late 1980s and 1990s, midnight movies transitioned from underground showings to home video viewings; eventually, a desire for community brought a resurgence, and ''The Big Lebowski'' kick-started a new generation. Demographics shifted, and more hip and mainstream audiences were drawn to them. Although studios expressed skepticism, large audiences were drawn to box office flops, such as ''[[Donnie Darko]]'' (2001), [[The Warriors (film)]] (1979) and ''[[Office Space]]'' (1999).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Palopoli|first=Steve|title=Cult Rapture|journal=[[Metro Silicon Valley]]|date=2003-09-17|url=http://www.metroactive.com/papers/cruz/09.17.03/cult-0338.html|accessdate=2013-07-28}}</ref> Modern midnight movies retain their popularity and have been strongly diverging from mainstream films shown at midnight. Mainstream cinemas, eager to disassociate themselves from negative associations and increase profits, have begun abandoning midnight screenings. Although classic midnight movies have dropped off in popularity, they still bring reliable crowds.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Olsen|first1=Mark|last2=Kaufman|first2=Amy|title=Moviegoing at the Midnight Hour|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/may/04/entertainment/la-et-mn-ca-new-midnight-movies-20130505|accessdate=2013-07-28|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=2013-05-04}}</ref>
===Art and exploitation=== Although seemingly at odds with each other, [[art film|art]] and [[exploitation film]]s are frequently treated as equal and interchangeable in cult fandom, listed alongside each other and described in similar terms: their ability to provoke a response. The most exploitative aspects of art films are thus played up and their academic recognition ignored.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hawkins|first=Joan|title=Cutting Edge: Art-Horror and the Horrific Avant-garde|year=2000|publisher=[[University of Minnesota Press]]|location=Minneapolis|isbn=0-8166-3413-0|pages=3–4|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=68whFPvH5VEC&pg=PA3|chapter=Sleaze-Mania, Euro-trash, and High Art}}</ref> This flattening of culture follows the popularity of [[post-structuralism]], which rejects a hierarchy of artistic merit and equates exploitation and art.<ref name=betz />{{rp|202–203}} Mathijs and Sexton state that although cult films are not synonymous with exploitation, as is occasionally assumed, this is a key component; they write that exploitation, which exists on the fringes of the mainstream and deals with [[taboo]] subjects, is well-suited for cult followings.<ref name=exploitation>{{cite book|first1=Ernest|last1=Mathijs|first2=Jamie|last2=Sexton|title=Cult Cinema|year=2012|publisher=[[Wiley & Sons]]|isbn=978-1-4443-9643-0|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uPtuaV7IAt0C&pg=PT180|chapter=Exploitation and B Movies}}</ref> Academic David Andrews writes that cult softcore films are "the most masculinized, youth-oriented, populist, and openly pornographic softcore area."<ref name=andrews>{{cite book|title=Soft in the Middle: The Contemporary Softcore Feature in Its Contexts|last=Andrews|first=David|publisher=[[Ohio State University Press]]|year=2006|isbn=978-0-8142-1022-2|page=8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Zk-F1B7RUfcC&pg=PT23}}</ref> The sexploitation films of [[Russ Meyer]] were among the first to abandon all hypocritical pretenses of morality and were technically proficient enough to gain a cult following.
