His persistent vision saw him received as an auteur worthy of academic study; director John Waters attributes this to Meyer's ability to create complicated, sexually charged films without resorting to explicit sex.<ref name=meyer />{{rp|5–7,14}} Myrna Oliver described [[Doris Wishman]]'s exploitation films as "crass, coarse, and camp ... perfect fodder for a cult following."<ref>{{cite news|last=Oliver|first=Myrna|title=Doris Wishman; Exploitation Film Director, Cult Favorite|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/aug/21/local/me-wishman21|accessdate=2013-07-29|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=2002-08-21}}</ref> "Sick films", the most disturbing and graphically transgressive films, have their own distinct cult following; these films transcend their roots in exploitation, horror, and art films.<ref name=mondo>{{cite book|title=Cult Cinema|last1=Mathijs|first1=Ernest|last2=Sexton|first2=Jamie|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]|year=2012|isbn=978-1-4443-9642-3|pages=105–107|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3EmSqIo4I-QC&pg=PA105|chapter=Transgression and Freakery}}</ref> In 1960s and 1970s America, exploitation and art films shared audiences and marketing, especially in New York City's [[grindhouse]] cinemas.<ref name=betz/>{{rp|219–220}}
===B and genre films=== Mathijs and Sexton state that [[film genre|genre]] is an important part of cult films; cult films will often mix, mock, or exaggerate the tropes associated with traditional genres.<ref name=mondo/> Science fiction, fantasy, and horror are known for their large and dedicated cult followings; as science fiction films become more popular, fans emphasize non-mainstream and less commercial aspects of it.<ref>{{cite book|title=Cult Cinema|last1=Mathijs|first=Ernest|last2=Sexton|first2=Jamie|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]|year=2011|isbn=978-1-4051-7374-2|pages=205–207|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ntg-1SAKgboC&pg=PA205|chapter=Cult Science Fiction Cinema}}</ref> [[B film]]s, which are often conflated with exploitation, are as important to cult films as exploitation.<ref name=exploitation/> Teodor Reljic of ''[[Malta Today]]'' states that cult B films are a realistic goal for Malta's burgeoning film industry.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.maltatoday.com.mt/arts/film/38734/are_cult_films_a_possibility_for_malta|title=Are 'cult' films a possibility for Malta?|last=Reljic|first=Teodor|work=[[Malta Today]]|date=2014-05-08|accessdate=2014-05-08}}</ref> Genre films, B films that strictly adhere to genre limitations, can appeal to cult film fans: given their transgressive excesses, horror films are likely to become to cult films;<ref name=midnight />{{rp|33}} films like ''[[Galaxy Quest]]'' (1999) highlight the importance of cult followings and fandom to science fiction;<ref>{{cite book|last=Geraghty|first=Lincoln|title=American science fiction film and television.|year=2009|publisher=[[Berg Publishers]]|location=Oxford|isbn=978-1-84520-795-3|page=102|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=agDbWF4qJCsC&pg=PA102}}</ref> and authentic martial arts skills in [[Hong Kong action cinema|Hong Kong action films]] can drive them to become cult favorites.<ref name=hunt />{{rp|157–159}} Cult musicals can range from the traditional, such as ''[[Singin' in the Rain]]'' (1952), which appeal to cult audiences through nostalgia, camp, and spectacle, to the more non-traditional, such as ''[[Cry-Baby]]'' (1990), which parodies musicals, and ''Rocky Horror'', which uses a rock soundtrack.<ref>{{cite book|title=Cult Cinema|last1=Mathijs|first1=Ernest|last2=Sexton|first2=Jamie|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]|year=2012|isbn=978-1-4443-9642-3|pages=175–177|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3EmSqIo4I-QC&pg=PA175|chapter=Cult Cinema and Music}}</ref> Romantic fairy tale ''[[The Princess Bride (film)|The Princess Bride]]'' (1987) failed to attract audiences in its original release, as the studio did not know how to market it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/10/07/princess-bride-reunion/|title=As you wish: 'Princess Bride' cast and director talk inconceivable(!) cult hit -- VIDEO|last=Rottenberg|first=Josh|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=2011-10-07|accessdate=2014-05-05}}</ref> The freedom and excitement associated with cars can be an important part of drawing cult film fans to genre films, and they can signify action and danger with more ambiguity than a gun.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/film/the-auto-motive-why-cars-drive-cult-movies/article11374759/|title=The auto motive: Why cars drive cult movies|last=Pevere|first=Geoff|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=2013-04-18|accessdate=2014-05-03}}</ref> ''[[Ad Week]]'' writes that cult B films, when released on home video, market themselves and need only enough advertising to raise curiosity or nostalgia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adweek.com/news/television/streamy-romance-americans-love-affair-b-movies-goes-digital-157724|title=Streamy Romance: Americans' Love Affair With B Movies Goes Digital|work=[[Ad Week]]|date=2014-05-21|accessdate=2014-05-29}}</ref>
===Animation=== [[Animation]] can provide wide open vistas for stories; the French film ''[[Fantastic Planet]]'' (1972) explored ideas beyond the limits of traditional, live-action science fiction films.<ref>{{cite news|last=Yagoda|first=Ben|title='Light Years' Ahead Of The Pack Animation Brings Rene Laloux's Sci-fi Vision To Life|url=http://articles.philly.com/1988-04-04/news/26253782_1_rene-laloux-light-years-david-johansen|accessdate=2013-08-01|newspaper=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]]|date=1988-04-04}}</ref> Phil Hoad of ''[[The Guardian]]'' identifies ''[[Akira (1988 film)|Akira]]'' (1988) as introducing violent, adult Japanese animation (known as [[anime]]) to the West and paving the way for later works.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hoad|first=Phil|title=Akira: the Future-Tokyo Story that Brought Anime West|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/jul/10/akira-anime-japanese-cartoon-manga|accessdate=2013-07-31|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=2013-07-10}}</ref> Anime, according to academic Brian Ruh, is not a cult genre, but the lack of individual fandoms inside [[anime fandom]] itself lends itself to a bleeding over of cult attention and can help spread works internationally. Anime, which is often highly franchised, provides its fans with alternative fictional canons and points of view that can drive fan activity. The ''[[Ghost in the Shell]]'' franchise, for example, provided Japanese fans with enough bonus material and spinoffs that it encouraged cult tendencies. Markets that did not support the sale of these materials saw less cult activity.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ruh|first=Brian|title=Producing Transnational Cult Media- Neon Genesis Evangelion and Ghost in the Shell in Circulation|journal=Intensities|date=Spring–Summer 2013|issue=5|url=http://intensitiescultmedia.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/producing-transnational-cult-media-neon-genesis-evangelion-and-ghost-in-the-shell-in-circulation-brian-ruh.pdf|accessdate=2013-07-30}}</ref> [[Ralph Bakshi]]'s career has been marked with controversy: ''[[Fritz the Cat (film)|Fritz the Cat]]'' (1972), the first animated film to be [[MPAA film rating system#X replaced by NC-17|rated "X" by the MPAA]], provoked outrage for its racial caricatures and graphic depictions of sex, and ''[[Coonskin (film)|Coonskin]]'' (1975) was decried as racist.<ref>{{cite news|last=Diamond|first=Jamie|title=Animation's Bad Boy Returns, Unrepentant|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/07/05/movies/film-animation-s-bad-boy-returns-unrepentant.html|accessdate=2013-07-31|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=1992-07-05}}</ref> Bakshi recalls that older animators had tired of "kid stuff" and desired edgier work, whereas younger animators hated his work for "destroying the Disney images". Eventually, his work would be reassessed and cult followings, which include [[Quentin Tarantino]] and [[Robert Rodriguez]], developed around several of his films.<ref>{{cite web|last=Huver|first=Scott|title=Animation Legend Ralph Bakshi Looks Back at His Cult Classic "Wizards"|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/blogs/popcornbiz/Ralph-Bakshis-Animated-Look-Back-at-His-Classic-Film-Wizards-142502455.html|work=[[KNTV]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|accessdate=2013-07-31|date=2012-05-30}}</ref> ''[[Heavy Metal (film)|Heavy Metal]]'' (1981) faced similar denunciations from critics; Donald Liebenson of the ''Los Angeles Times'' cites the violence and sexual imagery as alienating critics, who did not know what to make of the film. It would go on to become a popular midnight movie and frequently bootlegged by fans, as licensing issues kept it from being released on video for many years.<ref>{{cite news|last=Liebenson|first=Donald|title=Cult Favorite 'Heavy Metal' Once Again Making Noise|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-03-09/entertainment/ca-44792_1_heavy-metal|accessdate=2013-07-31|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=1996-03-09}}</ref>
===Nonfiction=== Sensationalistic documentaries called [[mondo film]]s replicate the most shocking and transgressive elements of exploitation films; they are usually modeled after "sick films" and cover similar subject matter.<ref name=mondo/> In ''[[The Cult Film Reader]]'', academics Mathijs and Mendik write that these documentaries often present non-Western societies as "stereotypically mysterious, seductive, immoral, deceptive, barbaric or savage".<ref name=mondo2>{{cite book|title=The Cult Film Reader|last1=Mathijs|first1=Ernest|last2=Mendik|first2=Xavier|publisher=[[McGraw-Hill International]]|year=2007|isbn=978-0-335-21923-0|pages=1–10|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dWX4AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA10|chapter=What Is Cult Film?}}</ref> Though they can be interpreted as racist, Mathijs and Mendik state that they also "exhibit a liberal attitude towards the breaking of cultural taboos".<ref name=mondo2/> Mondo films like ''[[Faces of Death]]'' mix real and fake footage freely, and they gain their cult following through the outrage and debate over authenticity that results.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sptimes.com/News/102600/Weekend/Lifting_the_mask_from.shtml|title=Lifting the mask from 'Faces of Death'|last=Welch|first=Michael Patrick|work=[[Tampa Bay Times]]|date=2000-10-26|accessdate=2014-05-03}}</ref> Like "so bad it's good" cult films, old propaganda and government hygiene films may be enjoyed ironically by more modern audiences for the camp value of the outdated themes and outlandish claims made about perceived social threats, such as drug use.<ref name="cult-intro"/> Academic Barry K. Grant states that [[Frank Capra]]'s ''[[Why We Fight]]'' World War II propaganda films are explicitly not cult, because they are "slickly made and have proven their ability to persuade an audience."<ref>{{cite book|title=The Cult Film Reader|editor1-last=Mathijs|editor1-first=Ernest|editor2-last=Mendik|editor2-first=Xavier|last=Grant|first=Barry K.|publisher=[[McGraw-Hill International]]|year=2007|isbn=978-0-335-21923-0|page=78|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dWX4AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA78|chapter=Science Fiction Double Feature: Ideology in the Cult Film}}</ref> The [[sponsored film]] ''[[Mr. B Natural]]'' became a cult hit when it was broadcast on the satirical television show ''[[Mystery Science Theater 3000]]'';<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/arts/index.ssf/2013/03/buzz_podewell_69_longtime_dire.html|title=Buzz Podewell, 69, longtime director and acting teacher, dies|last=Mahne|first=Theodore P.|work=[[The Times-Picayune]]|date=2013-03-29|accessdate=2014-05-03}}</ref> cast member [[Trace Beaulieu]] cited these educational shorts as his favorite to mock on the show.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/pop-culture/tv/robot-roll-call-mystery-science-theater-3000-cast-share-favorite-f2D11624170|title=Robot roll call! 'Mystery Science Theater 3000' cast share favorite episodes as show turns 25|last=Cooper|first=Gael Fashingbauer|work=[[NBC News]]|date=2013-11-24|accessdate=2014-05-03}}</ref> Mark Jancovich states that cult audiences are drawn to these films because of their "very banality or incoherence of their political positions", unlike traditional cult films, which achieve popularity through auteurist radicalism.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Cult Film Reader|last=Jancovich|first=Mark|editor1-last=Mathijs|editor1-first=Ernest|editor2-last=Mendik|editor2-first=Xavier|publisher=[[McGraw-Hill International]]|year=2007|isbn=978-0-335-21923-0|page=157|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dWX4AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA157|chapter=Cult Fictions}}</ref>
==Mainstream popularity== [[File:Quentin Tarantino by Gage Skidmore.jpg|thumb|alt=Quentin Tarantino sitting down, smiling|Quentin Tarantino is an example of a cult film director who has achieved mainstream success.]]
Mark Shiel explains the rising popularity of cult films as an attempt by cinephiles and scholars to escape the oppressive conformity and mainstream appeal of even independent film, as well as a lack of condescension in both critics and the films;<ref name=shiel /> Academic Donna de Ville says it is a chance to subvert the dominance of academics and cinephiles.<ref name=alamo /> According to Xavier Mendik, "academics have been really interested in cult movies for quite a while now." Mendik has sought to bring together academic interest and fandom through [[Cine-Excess]], a film festival.<ref name=sheep /> I. Q. Hunter states that "it's much easier to be a cultist now, but it is also rather more inconsequential."<ref name=cineaste /> Citing the mainstream availability of ''Cannibal Holocaust'', Jeffrey Sconce rejects definitions of cult films based on controversy and excess, as they've now become meaningless.<ref name=sconce>{{cite journal|jstor=41690732|title=Cult Cinema: A Critical Symposium|last=Sconce|first=Jeffrey|work=[[Cineaste (magazine)|Cineaste]]|volume=34|issue=1|pages=48–49|date=Winter 2008}}</ref> Cult films have influenced such diverse industries as cosmetics,<ref>{{cite news|last=Stover|first=Lauren|title=A Vegan With a Dark Side|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/30/fashion/a-vegan-with-a-dark-side.html|accessdate=2013-05-30|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=2013-05-29}}</ref> music videos,<ref name=borrowings /> and fashion.<ref>{{cite web|last=Collinson |first=Laura |title=Lights, Camera ... Fashion! |url=http://www.artslondonnews.co.uk/20110216_fashion-film |work=Arts London News |publisher=[[London College of Communication]] |accessdate=2013-06-03 |date=2011-02-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140420073219/http://www.artslondonnews.co.uk/20110216_fashion-film |archivedate=April 20, 2014 |df=mdy }}</ref> Cult films have shown up in less expected places; as a sign of his popularity, a bronze statue of [[Ed Wood]] has been proposed in his hometown,<ref>{{cite news|last=Musso|first=Anthony P.|title=Cult Figure Wood May Get Statue in His Honor|work=[[Poughkeepsie Journal]]|url=http://www.poughkeepsiejournal.com/article/20130529/NEWS01/305290018?nclick_check=1|accessdate=2013-05-30|date=2013-05-29}}</ref> and ''[[L'Osservatore Romano]]'', the official newspaper of the [[Holy See]], has courted controversy for its endorsement of cult films and pop culture.<ref>{{cite news|last=Squires|first=Nick|title=Vatican Declares the Blues Brothers a 'Catholic Classic'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/film-news/7835639/Vatican-declares-the-Blues-Brothers-a-Catholic-classic.html|accessdate=2013-05-31|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=2010-06-18}}</ref> When cities attempt to renovate neighborhoods, fans have called attempts to demolish iconic settings from cult films "cultural vandalism".<ref>{{cite news|last=Herbert|first=Ian|title=Fans of Cult Film Campaign to Save Car Park|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/fans-of-cult-film-campaign-to-save-car-park-710061.html|accessdate=2013-05-31|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=2000-07-20}}</ref> Cult films can also drive tourism,<ref>{{cite news|title=Cult Film Still Reels in Tourists |url=http://www.omaha.com/article/20091025/LIVING/710259921 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130616013259/http://www.omaha.com/article/20091025/LIVING/710259921 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=June 16, 2013 |accessdate=2013-05-31 |newspaper=[[The Omaha World Herald]] |date=2009-10-25 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |df= }}</ref> even when it is unwanted.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fiore|first=Faye|title=Cult Film 'Blair Witch' Was Tourist Horror Show for Small Town|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/travel/2012030605_weblairwitch04.html|accessdate=2013-05-31|newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=2010-06-06}}</ref>
As far back as the 1970s, ''[[Attack of the Killer Tomatoes]]'' (1978) was designed specifically to be a cult film,<ref>{{cite web|last=Firsching|first=Robert|title=Attack of the Killer Tomatoes!|url=http://www.allmovie.com/movie/v3267|work=[[Allmovie]]|publisher=[[Rovi]]|accessdate=2013-05-01}}</ref> and ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show'' was produced by [[20th Century Fox]], a major Hollywood studio. Over its decades-long release, ''Rocky Horror'' became the seventh highest grossing R-rated film when adjusted for inflation;<ref>{{cite web|title=The Rocky Horror Picture Show|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=rockyhorrorpictureshow.htm|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=2013-05-01}}</ref> Journalist Matt Singer has questioned whether ''Rocky Horror''{{'}}s popularity invalidates its cult status.<ref>{{cite web| last1=Hillis| first1=Aaron| last2=Orange| first2=Michelle| last3=Singer| first3=Matt| last4=Sweeney| first4=R. Emmet| last5=Willmore| first5=Alison| title=Gagging on the Kool-Aid: Cult Films We Just Don't Get| url=http://www.ifc.com/fix/2007/01/gagging-on-the-koolaid-cult-fi|work=[[IFC (U.S. TV channel)|IFC]]| accessdate=2013-05-16|date=2007-01-15}}</ref> Founded in 1974, [[Troma Entertainment]], an independent studio, would become known for both its cult following and cult films.<ref>{{cite book|last=McKendry|first=Rebekah|title=Cinema Inferno: Celluloid Explosions from the Cultural Margins|year=2010|publisher=[[Scarecrow Press]]|location=Lanham|isbn=978-0-8108-7657-6|page=164|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4aSF_sChKG0C&pg=PA164|editor1-last=Weiner|editor1-first=Robert G.|editor2-last=Cline|editor2-first=John|chapter=Chapter 9: Troma Entertainment}}</ref> In the 1980s, [[Danny Peary]]'s ''[[Cult Movies (book)|Cult Movies]]'' (1981) would influence director [[Edgar Wright]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Alter|first=Ethan|title=Pilgrim's Progress: Cult director Edgar Wright Guides Michael Cera in Genre-Bending Comic Romp|url=http://www.filmjournal.com/filmjournal/content_display/news-and-features/features/movies/e3ic2e2d16144df098a1f2524c1df7af988|work=[[Film Journal International]]|accessdate=2013-05-01|date=2010-07-20}}</ref> and film critic Scott Tobias of ''[[The A.V. Club]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tobias|first=Scott|title=The New Cult Canon: An Introduction|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/the-new-cult-canon-an-introduction-9808|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|accessdate=2013-05-01|date=2008-02-21}}</ref> The rise of home video would have a mainstreaming effect on cult films and cultish behavior, though some collectors would be unlikely to self-identify as cult film fans.<ref name=cineaste /> Film critic [[Joe Bob Briggs]] began reviewing [[drive-in theater]] and cult films, though he faced much criticism as an early advocate of [[exploitation film|exploitation]] and cult films. Briggs highlights the mainstreaming of cult films by pointing out the respectful obituaries that cult directors have received from formerly hostile publications and acceptance of politically incorrect films at mainstream film festivals.<ref name=joebob /> This acceptance is not universal, though, and some critics have resisted this mainstreaming of paracinema.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hawkins|first=Joan|title=Culture Wars: Some New Trends in Art Horror|journal=[[Jump Cut (journal)|Jump Cut]]|year=2009|issue=51|url=http://www.ejumpcut.org/archive/jc51.2009/artHorror/text.html|accessdate=2013-06-22}}</ref> Beginning in the 1990s, director [[Quentin Tarantino]] would have the greatest success in turning cult films mainstream.<ref name="not-cult" /><ref name="who-killed">{{cite news|last=Leigh|first=Danny|title=Who Killed Cult Movies?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2009/oct/13/who-killed-cult-movies|accessdate=2013-05-01|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=2009-10-13}}</ref> Tarantino later used his fame to champion obscure cult films that had influenced him and set up the short-lived [[Rolling Thunder Pictures]], which distributed several of his favorite cult films.<ref>{{cite news|last=Patterson|first=John|title=Quentin Tarantino: Champion of Trash Cinema|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/aug/17/quentin-tarantino-trash-cinema|accessdate=2013-05-01|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=2009-08-17}}</ref> Tarantino's clout led Phil Hoad of ''[[The Guardian]]'' to call Tarantino the world's most influential director.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hoad|first=Phil|title=Is Quentin Tarantino the World's Most Influential Director?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2013/jan/15/quentin-tarantino-most-influential-director|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=2013-05-16|date=2013-01-15}}</ref>
As major Hollywood studios and audiences both become savvy to cult films, productions once limited to cult appeal have instead become popular hits, and cult directors have become hot properties known for more mainstream and accessible films.<ref name=metro /> Remarking on the popular trend of remaking cult films, Claude Brodesser-Akner of ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine states that Hollywood studios have been superstitiously hoping to recreate past successes rather than trading on nostalgia.<ref>{{cite web|last=Brodesser-Akner|first=Claude|title=Why Do Studios Think There's So Much Value in Old Titles?| url=http://www.vulture.com/2011/08/conan_the_barbarian_fright_nig.html| work=Vulture| publisher=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]| accessdate=2013-05-31| date=2011-08-19}}</ref> Their popularity would bring some critics to proclaim the death of cult films now that they have finally become successful and mainstream,<ref name="who-killed" /> are too slick to attract a proper cult following,<ref name="cult-dead" /> lack context,<ref name=sconce /> or are too easily found online.<ref>{{cite web|last=Harris|first=Brandon|title=The Internet and the Cult Film: On A Fan's Notes|url=http://filmmakermagazine.com/65996-the-internet-and-the-cult-film-on-a-fans-notes/|work=Filmmaker|accessdate=2013-05-13|date=2013-04-04}}</ref> In response, David Church says that cult film fans have retreated to more obscure and difficult to find films, often using illegal distribution methods, which preserves the outlaw status of cult films. Virtual spaces, such as online forums and fan sites, replace the traditional [[fanzine]]s and newsletters.<ref name=cineaste /> Cult film fans consider themselves collectors, rather than consumers, as they associate consumers with mainstream, Hollywood audiences.<ref name=hollows />{{rp|46}} This collecting can take the place of fetishization of a single film.<ref name=sconce /> Addressing concerns that DVDs have revoked the cult status of films like ''Rocky Horror'', academic Mikel J. Koven states that small scale screenings with friends and family can replace midnight showings. Koven also identifies television shows, such as ''[[Twin Peaks]]'', as retaining more traditional cult activities inside popular culture.<ref name=cineaste /> [[David Lynch]] himself has not ruled out another television series, as studios have become reluctant to take chances on non-mainstream ideas.<ref>{{cite news|last=Walker|first=Tim|title=Waxing Lyrical: David Lynch on His New Passion - and Why He May Never Make Another Movie|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/waxing-lyrical-david-lynch-on-his-new-passion--and-why-he-may-never-make-another-movie-8665457.html|accessdate=2013-06-28|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=2013-06-23}}</ref> Despite this, the [[Alamo Drafthouse]] has capitalized on cult films and the surrounding culture through inspiration drawn from ''Rocky Horror'' and retro promotional gimmickry. They sell out their shows regularly and have acquired a cult following of their own.<ref name=alamo />
Academic Bob Batchelor, writing in ''Cult Pop Culture'', states that the internet has democratized cult culture and destroyed the line between cult and mainstream. Fans of even the most obscure films can communicate online with each other in vibrant communities.<ref>{{cite book|last=Batchelor|first=Bob|title=Cult Pop Culture: How the Fringe Became Mainstream: How the Fringe Became Mainstream, Volume 1|year=2011|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|isbn=978-0-313-35781-7|pages=xii-xiii|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jqd92sX1hAoC&pg=PR12|chapter=Introduction}}</ref> Although known for their big-budget [[blockbuster (entertainment)|blockbusters]], [[Steven Spielberg]] and [[George Lucas]] have criticized the current Hollywood system of gambling everything on the opening weekend of these productions. Geoffrey Macnab of ''[[The Independent]]'' instead suggests that Hollywood look to capitalize on cult films, which have exploded in popularity on the internet.<ref>{{cite news|last=Macnab|first=Geoffrey|title=Cult Classics Take on the Blockbusters as Audiences Switch on to Internet Downloads|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/cult-classics-take-on-the-blockbusters-as-audiences-switch-on-to-internet-downloads-877798.html|accessdate=2013-05-09|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=2008-07-26}}</ref> The rise of [[social media]] has been a boon to cult films. Sites such as [[Twitter]] have displaced traditional venues for fandom and courted controversy from cultural critics who are unamused by campy cult films.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Crouch|first=Ian|title=We Watched "Sharknado"|journal=[[The New Yorker]]|date=2013-07-12|url=http://www.newyorker.com/culture/culture-desk/we-watched-sharknado|accessdate=2013-07-16}}</ref> After a clip from one of his films went [[viral video|viral]], director-producer [[Roger Corman]] made a distribution deal with [[YouTube]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Nakashima|first=Ryan|title=For new YouTube, You Pay|url=http://www.sfltimes.com/soflo-live/entertainment/for-new-youtube-you-pay|accessdate=2013-05-22|newspaper=South Florida Times|date=2013-05-22|agency=[[Associated Press]]}}</ref> [[Found footage (appropriation)|Found footage]] which had originally been distributed as cult VHS collections eventually went viral on YouTube, which opened them to new generations of fans.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Smith|first=Iain Robert|title=Collecting the Trash: The Cult of the Ephemeral Clip from VHS to YouTube|journal=[[Flow (journal)|Flow]]|date=2011-09-16|volume=14|issue=8|url=http://flowtv.org/2011/09/collecting-the-trash/|accessdate=2013-06-21}}</ref> Films such as ''[[Birdemic]]'' (2008) and ''[[The Room (film)|The Room]]'' (2003) gained quick, massive popularity, as prominent members of social networking sites discussed them. Their rise as "instant cult classics" bypasses the years of obscurity that most cult films labor under.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lemire |first=Christy |title=Schlockey Films Gain Instant Cult Status via Net |url=http://www.businessweek.com/ap/tech/D9FI2T4G0.htm |accessdate=2013-05-11 |newspaper=[[Business Week]] |date=2010-05-07 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151120122004/http://www.businessweek.com/ap/tech/D9FI2T4G0.htm |archivedate=November 20, 2015 |df=mdy }}</ref> In response, critics have described the use of [[viral marketing]] as [[astroturfing]] and an attempt to manufacture cult films.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lee|first=Chris|title=How to Build a Nerd Film Cult|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/jun/26/entertainment/et-lee26|accessdate=2013-05-13|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=2004-06-26}}</ref>
I. Q. Hunter identifies a prefabricated cult film style which includes "deliberately, insulting bad films", "slick exercises in dysfunction and alienation", and mainstream films "that sell themselves as worth obsessing over".<ref name=cineaste /> Writing for [[NPR]], Scott Tobias states that [[Don Coscarelli]], whose previous films effortlessly attracted cult followings, has drifted into this realm. Tobias criticizes Coscarelli as trying too hard to appeal to cult audiences and sacrificing internal consistency for calculated quirkiness.<ref>{{cite news|last=Tobias|first=Scott|title=Spoiler Alert: 'John Dies,' But The Rest? Who Can Tell?|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/01/24/170011522/spoiler-alert-john-dies-but-the-rest-who-can-tell|accessdate=2013-06-23|newspaper=[[National Public Radio]]|date=2013-01-24}}</ref> Influenced by the successful online hype of ''[[The Blair Witch Project]]'' (1999), other films have attempted to draw online cult fandom with the use of prefabricated cult appeal. ''[[Snakes on a Plane]]'' (2006) is an example that attracted massive attention from curious fans. Uniquely, its cult following preceded the film's release and included speculative parodies of what fans imagined the film might be. This reached the point of [[technological convergence#Convergence culture|convergence culture]] when fan speculation began to impact on the film's production.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Stevens|first=Kirsten|editor1-last=Cash|editor1-first=Conall|editor2-last=Snow|editor2-first=Samuel Cuff|title=Snakes on a Plane and the Prefabricated Cult Film|journal=Colloquy|year=2009|issue=18|url=http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/colloquy/download/colloquy_issue_eighteen/stevens.pdf|accessdate=2013-06-23|publisher=[[Monash University]]}}</ref> Although it was proclaimed a cult film and major game-changer before it was released,<ref>{{cite news|last=Chonin|first=Neva|title='Snakes on a Plane' Blog Buzz Forces Hollywood into Overdue Attitude Adjustment|url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Snakes-on-a-Plane-blog-buzz-forces-Hollywood-2533141.php|accessdate=2013-05-13|newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date=2006-06-12}}</ref> it failed to win either mainstream audiences or maintain its cult following. In retrospect, critic Spencer Kornhaber would call it a serendipitous novelty and a footnote to a "more naive era of the Internet".<ref>{{cite news|last=Kornhaber|first=Spencer|title='Snakes on a Plane,' 5 Years Later|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2011/08/snakes-on-a-plane-5-years-later/243790/|accessdate=2013-05-13|newspaper=[[The Atlantic]]|date=2011-08-18}}</ref> However, it became influential in both marketing<ref>{{cite web|last=Carle|first=Chris|title=Snakes on a Plane|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/01/02/snakes-on-a-plane|work=[[IGN]]|accessdate=2013-05-13|date=2007-01-02}}</ref> and titling.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Suddath|first=Claire|title=Cowboys, Aliens, Snakes and Sharks: In Praise of Literal Movie Titles|url=http://content.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,2086635,00.html|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|accessdate=2013-05-13|date=2011-08-04}}</ref> This trend of "instant cult classics" which are hailed yet fail to attain a lasting following is described by Matt Singer, who states that the phrase is an oxymoron.<ref name="kool-aid">{{cite web|last=Singer|first=Matt|title=Pass the Kool-Aid: Five Flicks That Aspired To Cult Status|url=http://www.ifc.com/fix/2008/11/pass-the-koolaid-five-movies-t|work=[[IFC (U.S. TV channel)|IFC]]|accessdate=2013-05-20|date=2008-11-06}}</ref>
Cult films are often approached in terms of [[auteur theory]], which states that the director's creative vision drives a film. This has fallen out of favor in academia, creating a disconnect between cult film fans and critics.<ref name=hutchings />{{rp|135}} Matt Hills states that auteur theory can help to create cult films; fans that see a film as continuing a director's creative vision are likely to accept it as cult.<ref name=cineaste /> According to academic Greg Taylor, auteur theory also helped to popularize cult films when middlebrow audiences found an accessible way to approach avant-garde film criticism. Auteur theory provided an alternative culture for cult film fans while carrying the weight of scholarship. By requiring repeated viewings and extensive knowledge of details, auteur theory naturally appealed to cult film fans. Taylor further states that this was instrumental in allowing cult films to break through to the mainstream.<ref>{{cite book|last=Taylor|first=Greg|title=Artists in the Audience: Cults, Camp, and American Film Criticism|year=2001|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|isbn=978-0-691-08955-3|pages=87–88|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fukKSOOc0dYC&pg=PA87}}</ref> Academic Joe Tompkins states that this auteurism is often highlighted when mainstream success occurs. This may take the place of – and even ignore – political readings of the director. Cult films and directors may be celebrated for their transgressive content, daring, and independence, but Tompkins argues that mainstream recognition requires they be palatable to corporate interests who stand to gain much from the mainstreaming of cult film culture. While critics may champion revolutionary aspects of filmmaking and political interpretation, Hollywood studios and other corporate interests will instead highlight only the aspects that they wish to legitimize in their own films, such as sensational exploitation. Someone like [[George Romero]], whose films are both transgressive and subversive, will have the transgressive aspects highlighted while the subversive aspects are ignored.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Tompkins|first=Joe|title="They Have the Oscars": Oppositional Telebranding and the Cult of the Horror Auteur|journal=[[Flow (journal)|Flow]]|date=2010-07-16|volume=12|issue=4|url=http://flowtv.org/2010/07/oppositional-telebranding-and-the-cult-of-the-horror-auteur/|accessdate=2013-06-21}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Film}} * [[Cult video game]] * [[List of cult films]] * [[Sleeper hit]]

'''Denitrifying bacteria''' are a diverse group of [[bacteria]] that encompass many different phyla. This group of bacteria, together with denitrifying fungi and archaea, is capable of performing [[denitrification]] as part of the [[nitrogen cycle]].<ref name=Zumft /> They [[metabolism|metabolise]] [[nitrogen]]ous [[Chemical compound|compounds]] using various enzymes, turning [[nitrogen oxide]]s back to nitrogen [[gas]] or [[nitrous oxide]].
== Diversity of denitrifying bacteria ==
There is a great diversity in bacteria capable of performing denitrification. Members of this group encompass most bacterial phyla and therefore possess a wide variety of physiological traits.<ref name="Zumft">Zumft, W. G. (1997). ''Cell biology and molecular basis of denitrification.'' Microbiology and Molecular Biology Reviews, 61(4), 533–616</ref> Denitrifying bacteria have been identified in over 50 genera with over 125 different species and are estimated to represent 10-15% of bacteria population in water, soil and sediment.<ref name="Eldor">Eldor, A. (2015). ''Soil microbiology, ecology, and biochemistry'' (4th ed.). Chapter 14 Amsterdam: Elsevier.</ref> Denitrifying include for example several species of ''[[Pseudomonas]]'', ''[[Alkaligene]]s'' , ''[[Bacillus]]'' and others. The majority of denitrifying bacteria are facultative aerobic heterotrophs that switch from aerobic respiration to denitrification when oxygen as an available terminal electron acceptor (TEA) runs out. This forces the organism to use nitrate to be used as a TEA.<ref name=Zumft /> Because the diversity of denitrifying bacteria is so large, this group can thrive in a wide range of habitats including some extreme environments such as environments that are highly saline and high in temperature.<ref name=Zumft /> Aerobic denitrifiers can conduct an aerobic respiratory process in which nitrate is converted gradually to N<sub>2</sub> (NO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup> →NO<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup> → NO → N<sub>2</sub>O → N<sub>2</sub> ), using nitrate reductase (Nar or Nao), nitrite reductase (Nir), nitric oxide reductase (Nor), and nitrous oxide reductase (Nos). Phylogenetic analysis revealed that aerobic denitrifiers mainly belong to α-, β- and γ-''Proteobacteria''<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ji|first=Bin|last2=Yang|first2=Kai|last3=Zhu|first3=Lei|last4=Jiang|first4=Yu|last5=Wang|first5=Hongyu|last6=Zhou|first6=Jun|last7=Zhang|first7=Huining|date=August 2015|title=Aerobic denitrification: A review of important advances of the last 30 years|journal=Biotechnology and Bioprocess Engineering|language=en|volume=20|issue=4|pages=643–651|doi=10.1007/s12257-015-0009-0|issn=1226-8372}}</ref>.
== Denitrification mechanism ==
Denitrifying bacteria use denitrification to generate ATP.<ref name="Bothe">Bothe, H., Ferguson, S., & Newton, W. (2007). ''Biology of the nitrogen cycle.'' Amsterdam: Elsevier.</ref>
The most common denitrification process is outlined below, with the nitrogen oxides being converted back to gaseous nitrogen:
2 NO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup> + 10 e<sup>−</sup> + 12 H<sup>+</sup> → N<sub>2</sub> + 6 H<sub>2</sub>O
The result is one molecule of nitrogen and six molecules of water. Denitrifying bacteria are a part of the N cycle, and consists of sending the N back into the atmosphere. The reaction above is the overall half reaction of the process of denitrification. The reaction can be further divided into different half reactions each requiring a specific enzyme. The transformation from nitrate to nitrite is performed by nitrate reductase (Nar)
NO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup> + 2 H<sup>+</sup> + 2 e<sup>−</sup> → NO<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup> + H<sub>2</sub>O
Nitrite reductase (Nir) then converts nitrite into nitric oxide
2 NO<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup> + 4 H<sup>+</sup> + 2 e<sup>−</sup> → 2 NO + 2 H<sub>2</sub>O
Nitric oxide reductase (Nor) then converts nitric oxide into nitrous oxide
2 NO + 2 H<sup>+</sup> + 2 e<sup>−</sup> → N<sub>2</sub>O + H<sub>2</sub>O
Nitrous oxide reductase (Nos) terminates the reaction by converting nitrous oxide into dinitrogen
N<sub>2</sub>O + 2 H<sup>+</sup> + 2 e<sup>−</sup> → N<sub>2</sub> + H<sub>2</sub>O
It is important to note that any of the products produced at any step can be exchanged with the soil environment.<ref name="Bothe" />
== Denitrifying bacteria and the environment ==
The process of denitrification can lower the fertility of soil as nitrogen, a growth-limiting factor, is removed from the soil and lost to the atmosphere. This loss of nitrogen to the atmosphere can eventually be regained via introduced nutrients, as part of the nitrogen cycle. Some nitrogen may also be [[nitrogen fixation|fixated]] by species of [[nitrifying bacteria]] and the [[cyanobacteria]]. Another important environmental issue concerning denitrification is the fact that the process tends to produce large amounts of by-products. Examples of by-products are nitric oxide (NO) and nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O). NO is an ozone depleting species and N<sub>2</sub>O is a potent greenhouse gas which can contribute to global warming.<ref name=Eldor />

{{Infobox artist | honorific_prefix = | name = <!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name --> | honorific_suffix = | image = UniShow Kelm 10ft Sky Ride plain 3x4w.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1972|01|26}} | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | nationality = | residence = [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]], [[United States of America]] | education = | alma_mater = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | movement = | spouse = | partner = | awards = {{awd|World Champion|1998|Men's Expert Freestyle|International Unicycle Federation}} | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = {{URL|UniShow.org}} | module = }} '''Dustin Kelm''' is a professional world champion and world record setting [[unicyclist]], performing the [https://unishow.org/ UniShow] around the world. He has performed and competed throughout North, South and Central America, Europe, Asia, Africa and the Caribbean. Dustin is a three time [http://www.uniusa.org Unicycling Society of America] expert freestyle national champion, a [http://www.uniusa.org Unicycling Society of America] mountain unicycling national champion and a [[UNICON]] freestyle World Champion.
He was born January 26, 1972 and was given his first unicycle at the age of 10. Two years later he joined the Twin Cities Unicycle Club in [[Minneapolis]] and discovered there was much more he could do on a unicycle besides his paper route. Over the years he has claimed national and world records, titles and medals in age group categories as well as men's expert categories.
Dustin was elected to serve on the board of directors for the Unicycling Society of America for two three year terms from 1989-1991, 1993-1995.<ref>{{cite journal|title=On One Wheel|date=1989–90|volume=XVI|issue=4|pages=4–5|editor1-first=Carol|editor1-last=Brichford|publisher=Unicycling Society of America, Inc.}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=On One Wheel|date=Summer 1995|volume=21|issue=3|page=11|editor1-first=Constance|editor1-last=Cotter|publisher=Unicycling Society of America, Inc.}}</ref> [[File:Istanbul Jump.jpg|thumb|Dustin Kelm street performing on Istiklal Avenue in Istanbul Turkey.]]

== Other competitions == *2004 - First place in Collins Cycles Extreme Freeride competition in [[Eugene, Oregon]] *2008 - Competed in the 800 kilometer [[Ride the Lobster]] unicycle race across [[Nova Scotia]], Canada
== RefugeRide == [[File:Refuge Ride - Dustin and Katie Kelm.jpg|thumb|Dustin and Katie Kelm travel through Wyoming on their cross country Refuge Ride to raise support and awareness for Syrian refugees in 2013.]] Dustin and his wife Katie accomplished the RefugeRide from June 21 to October 9, 2013, riding big wheel unicycles coast to coast across the United States from [[Tybee Island, Georgia]] to [[Yachats, Oregon]] to raise funds for Syrian refugees. In 97 days they rode 3,511 miles (5,650 kilometers) through 14 states, raising over $37,500.<ref>{{cite journal|title=On One Wheel|date=January 2014|issue=36-1|pages=10|author=Unicycling Society of America, Inc.|editor1-first=Shelly|editor1-last=Stobierski|issn=0893-4606|url=http://uniusa.org/wp-content/uploads/oow36-1.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Welch|first=Bob|title=Two on one ride|newspaper=Register Guard|date=7 October 2013|location=Eugene, OR}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Refuge Ride|newspaper=Siuslaw News|date=October 12, 2013|author=Ryan Cronk|pages=1,6A}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Unicycles Visit the Chamber|newspaper=About Town|date=October 1, 2013|author=Sharlene McCaslin|page=8}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Couple one-wheel across the country|newspaper=The Oberlin Herald|date=September 4, 2013|author=Ramell Taylor|pages=1,8A}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{Infobox Convention | name = EOY Cosplay Festival | image = [[Image:eoylogo.jpg|255px]] | caption = EOY's logo | status = Active | country = [[Singapore]] | attendance = 20,000+ in 2013 <ref name="20,000+ Guests at EOY Cosplay Festival 2013! Thank You!">{{cite web | url = http://theeoy.com/2013/20000-guests-at-eoy-cosplay-festival-2013-thank-you/ | title = 20,000+ Guests at EOY Cosplay Festival 2013! Thank You! | publisher = TheEOY.com | accessdate = 19 February 2011}}</ref> | website = http://www.theeoy.com }}
'''EOY Cosplay Festival''', also known as the "End of Year" Cosplay Festival, is a Japanese pop-cultural arts event that is [[non-profit]] and fan-run [[multigenre convention]] featuring [[anime]], [[cosplay]], [[doujin works]], [[subculture fashion]] and Japanese pop music held in [[Singapore]]. Since 2012, it has become a free public event.
Its highlights include the hundreds of cosplayers who visit each year, generous opportunities for cosplay photography, guest performances by Japanese celebrities, music and dance performances by home-grown talents, artwork exhibitions and booths selling anime merchandise and personal artworks.<ref name="EOY Official Website">{{cite web | url = http://www.theeoy.com | title = EOY Official Website | publisher = TheEOY.com | accessdate = 19 February 2011}}</ref>
Alongside the annual events, EOY also partners related organisations to hold periodic events and performances related to anime, cosplay and [[music]]. Notable ones include the Singapore Silver Cosplay Club cosplay competition, Walk for Our Children ([[Singapore Children’s Society]]), [[Tao (musical troupe)|TAO]] “Art of Drum”, Liang Court Anime Week, Bon Japan Theme Cafes, SGCafe Maid and Butler Cafe and [[Marie Digby]]'s Your Love Asia Tour.<ref name="Event Production">{{cite web | url = http://theeoy.com/2013/about-us/event-production/ | title = Event Production | publisher = TheEOY.com | accessdate = 28 February 2014}}</ref><ref name="Marie Digby Your Love Asia Tour">{{cite web | url = http://theeoy.com/2013/about-us/event-production/marie-digby-your-love-asian-tour/ | title = Marie Digby Your Love Asia Tour | publisher = TheEOY.com | accessdate = 28 February 2014}}</ref><ref name="SGCafe Maid and Butler Cafe">{{cite web | url = http://theeoy.com/2013/sgcafe-maid-and-butler-cafe/ | title = SGCafe Maid and Butler Cafe | publisher = TheEOY.com | accessdate = 28 February 2014}}</ref>
== Celebrity appearances == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Aikawa Kozue and Ikura at EOY 2010's Autograph Session.JPG|thumb|250px|Danceroid members Aikawa Kozue and Ikura posing for con attendees and photographers at EOY 2010.]] --> * [[Yui Makino]] (2009) [[File:EOY 2009 Yui Makino.jpg|thumb|right|Yui Makino performing at EOY 2009]] Yui Makino, Japanese [[voice actor]], actress, singer and pianist, best known for her voice-acting and music works in the anime [[Tsubasa Chronicle]] and [[Aria]], gave two concerts; a 15-minute-long mini concert and a full-length 45-minute-long concert. Songs performed included "Fuwa Fuwa", "Amrita" and theme songs from ''Tsubasa Chronicle'' and ''Aria''.<ref name="Yui Makino's performance at EOY 2009">{{cite web | url = http://pzportal.net/main/event/yui-makino-interview-eoy-09 | title = Yui Makino Interview – EOY 09 | publisher = PZPortal.net | accessdate = 19 February 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101119201259/http://pzportal.net/main/event/yui-makino-interview-eoy-09/ | archivedate = 19 November 2010 | df = }}</ref><ref name="Yui Makino's performance at EOY 2009 -2">{{cite web | url = http://www.thebanzaieffect.com/articles/ooga/makino-yui-mini-performance-eoy-09/ | title = Makino Yui Mini Performance @ EOY 09 | publisher = TheBanzaiEffect.com | accessdate = 19 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="Yui Makino's EOY 2009 Appearance">{{cite web | url = http://ameblo.jp/yui-makino/entry-10429497400.html | title = Yui Makino Ameblo Entry 2010-01-08 | publisher = Yui Makino's Official Blog | accessdate = 19 February 2011}}</ref> She also held two autograph sessions and a Q-and-A session with the audience. Prior to her appearance, she made a special comment video.<ref name="Yui Makino's Comments for EOY 2009">{{cite web | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ViQAKNHlac4 | title = Yui Makino Comments Singapore EOY 2009 "An Extraordinary Journey | publisher = KyuuketsukiTim's Youtube | accessdate = 19 February 2011}}</ref>
* [[DANCEROID]] (2010), comprising ** [[Aikawa Kozue]] ** Ikura Aikawa Kozue and Ikura (also known as Itokutora), Japanese dancing [[net idol]]s best known for their self-choreographed dances to [[Vocaloid]] tunes on YouTube and [[Nico Nico Douga]], gave two dancicals. They performed duets to "Luka Luka ★ Night Fever", "FirstKiss!","Gravity=Reality", "Megu Megu ☆ Fire Endless Night", "Lily Lily ★ Burning Night" and "LOL -lots of laugh-". Ikura and Aikawa Kozue each performed a solo dance to "Strobe Night" and "Teach me!! The Lyrics of Magic" respectively. They also did a mass dance with the audience to "Luka Luka ★ Night Fever", where some members of the audience were allowed to join them on stage.<ref name="Danceroid's performance at EOY 2010">{{cite web | url = http://pzportal.net/main/event/eoy-danceroid/ | title = EOY 2010 – DANCEROID | publisher = PZPortal.net | accessdate = 19 February 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110223204848/http://pzportal.net/main/event/eoy-danceroid/ | archivedate = 23 February 2011 | df = }}</ref> An autograph session and a Q-and-A session with the audience were held.<ref name="EOY 2010 Event Details">{{cite web | url = http://www.theeoy.com/eoy2010 | title = EOY 2010 Event Details | publisher = TheEOY.com | accessdate = 19 February 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110120004227/http://www.theeoy.com/eoy2010/ | archivedate = 20 January 2011 | df = }}</ref><ref name="Ikura's EOY 2010 REPO">{{cite web | url = http://ameblo.jp/ikura-uniuni/entry-10735401615.html | title = Ikura's EOY 2010 Repo | publisher = Ikura's Official Blog | accessdate = 19 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="Aikawa Kozue's EOY 2010 REPO">{{cite web | url = http://ameblo.jp/aikawa-kozue/entry-10735281696.html | title = Aikawa Kozue's EOY 2010 Repo | publisher = Aikawa Kozue's Official Blog | accessdate = 19 February 2011}}</ref>
* Hitomi from @home Cafe (2011)
Hitomi hails from @home Cafe, a famous [[maid café]] in [[Akihabara]], Tokyo. Apart from serving food in a very '[[moe (slang)|moe]]' way, drawing cute pictures on dishes and casting magical spells on food, Hitomi also delivers singing and dancing performances regularly at @home Cafe. In addition, she is part of a J-pop duo, Team JJ,<ref name="Team Junjo">{{cite web | url = http://www.l-up.co.jp/management/talent | title = Link-Up Management Artiste List | publisher = Link-Up Management | accessdate = 16 October 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111129010934/http://www.l-up.co.jp/management/talent/ | archivedate = 29 November 2011 | df = }}</ref> which has performed live concerts and released CDs and DVDs in Japan. Hitomi delivered a 45-minute-long song and dance performance at EOY 2011, and served lunch to the VIP ticket holders.<ref name="EOY ’11 x Hitomi (@home)">{{cite web | url = http://www.theeoy.com/2011/2011/10/hitomi-from-home-maid-cafe-eoy-2011-guest-artiste/ | title = EOY ’11 x Hitomi (@home) | publisher = EOY | accessdate = 15 October 2011}}</ref>
* Wata わた (2013) Wata<ref name="Wata's Niconico Douga Page">{{cite web | url = http://www.nicovideo.jp/mylist/21343299 | title = Wata's Niconico Douga Page | publisher = Niconico Douga | accessdate = 28 February 2014}}</ref> is a pop dancer who shot to fame after posting videos of her energetic dances to [[Nico Nico Douga]]. She performed 2 sets of dances EOY Coslay Festival 2013 spanning over an approximate time of 40minutes, and a flashmob with a group of local dancers. She also held a meet-and-greet-session, where merchandise including T-shirts, towels, wristbands and phone straps were on sale.<ref name="A Handy Guide to EOY Cosplay Festival 2013">{{cite web | url = http://theeoy.com/2013/a-handy-guide-to-eoy-cosplay-festival-2013/ | title = A Handy Guide to EOY Cosplay Festival 2013 | publisher = EOY | accessdate = 28 February 2014}}</ref>
== Local Talents ==
Each year, EOY holds auditions for locally based singers, dancers and musicians who wish to get stage time at EOY. Popular types of music used in these performances include anime theme songs and Japanese [[pop music|pop]]. The performances run from afternoon to evening.
== Shift to Cosplay Festival Concept with Free Admission ==
In 2012, EOY made a shift from the typical paid indoor convention model to a public festival in the open that was free. EOY Cosplay Festival 2012 was held in Marina Barrage and attained a huge jump in attendance from 4000 in 2011 to over 10,000 in 2012.<ref name="EOY Cosplay Festival 2012 Report">{{cite web | url = http://theeoy.com/2013/cosplay-festival/ | title = EOY Cosplay Festival 2012 Report | publisher = TheEOY.com | accessdate = 19 February 2011}}</ref> In 2013, the attendance was doubled to 20,000.
[[File:EOY 2012 Cosplayers.jpg|thumb|right|Cosplayers and photographers at EOY Cosplay Festival 2012]] [[File:EOY 2012 Booth.jpg|thumb|right|Doujin and Anime Merchandise Booths at EOY Cosplay Festival 2012]]
Aside from stage performances and cosplay photography, the festival also features other fringe activities, depending on participating sponsors and exhibitors.
Activities featured in recent years:
[[File:Dokidokiheartscafe.jpg|thumb|right|Staff profile picture of Doki Doki Hearts Cafe]] * Doki Doki Hearts Cafe: In 2012, EOY organised its very own [[Cosplay Cafe]]. The staff, clad in costumes of their favourite characters, were selected through auditions, and were made to undergo training. At the cafe, they serve desserts to customers while staying in character of whoever they’re cosplaying. Cafe guests were treated to desserts from local Japanese-French dessert shop Sashing Sweets, “power-up” chants by the staff, and also get their photo taken with their favourite cafe staff. For its first year, it was highly successful, having attracted over 300 orders via preorder and walk-in.<ref name="EOY Cosplay Festival 2013 Report">{{cite web | url = http://theeoy.com/2013/eoy-cosplay-festival-2013-report/ | title = EOY Cosplay Festival 2013 Report | publisher = TheEOY.com | accessdate = 19 February 2011}}</ref> * Cosplay Photography Exhibition: Local photographer Tan Ching Yee visited, interviewed and photographed more than 20 cosplayers in their homes and put together a unique exhibition featuring portraits of cosplayers that reveal hints of their private lives.<ref name="Offstage A Solo Exhibition by Tan Ching Yee">{{cite web | url = http://theeoy.com/2013/offstage-a-solo-exhibition-by-tan-ching-yee/ | title = "Offstage" A Solo Exhibition by Tan Ching Yee | publisher = TheEOY.com | accessdate = 19 February 2011}}</ref> * [[Ball-jointed doll]] Display Booth: An exhibition booth put together by the local doll collector community, they created a Japanese Garden Theme Doll display booth called "Sakura Blossom of the Spring” with beautiful backdrops, detailed props, and dolls in traditional Japanese clothing.<ref name="Sakura Blossom of the Spring Doll Display Booth">{{cite web | url = http://theeoy.com/2013/sakura-blossom-of-the-spring-doll-display-booth/ | title = Sakura Blossom of the Spring Doll Display Booth | publisher = TheEOY.com | accessdate = 19 February 2011}}</ref> * [[Lolita Fashion]] Runway: A runway made up of and designed by girls the Lolita community in Singapore, showcasing Lolita clothing as worn in Singapore. * Cosplay Contest : In 2013, [[Singapore Press Holdings]] held an online cosplay photo submission contest. Judging is done via public voting and by a panel of judges and the prizes were presented on stage at EOY Cosplay Festival 2013.<ref name="Be A Cosplay Star Contest">{{cite web | url = http://theeoy.com/2013/cosplay-contest/ | title = "Be A Cosplay Star" Contest | publisher = TheEOY.com | accessdate = 19 February 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131116144730/http://theeoy.com/2013/cosplay-contest/ | archivedate = 16 November 2013 | df = }}</ref>
To cope with the costs of funding the event, the organising team seeks out sponsors and partners to provide financial and in-kind support. These sponsors and partners include [[Singapore Press Holdings]], [[Wacom (company)|Wacom]], [[Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation|OCBC]], Bunka Language Pte. School, Pan-In-The-Box, Brigitte Cosmetics, ACS Comics, Toy Coin, Happy Ice Pte Ltd, BonJapan, Youth.SG, Sapporo Beer Singapore, Orchard Hotel Singapore, PAssion Card, Coca-Cola Singapore, Pink Blue Photography, Platiper Software, Sashing Sweets, [[Baby the Stars Shine Bright]] and [[Shiseido]].
== Event History ==
EOY was first organized by MAC in the early years. The Shiro Tsubasa Anime Club (STAC) took over the management of the event until 2008. From 2009, EOY has been run by EOY LLP.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Date !! Event Theme !! Venue |- | Pre-2009 || NA || NA || [[Singapore Expo]] |- | 2009 || 26 December || An Extraordinary Journey || Drama Centre, The [[National Library, Singapore]] |- | 2010 || 12 December || Fun, Creativity and Friendship || Republic Cultural Centre, [[Republic Polytechnic]] |- | 2011 || 17 December || A Day of Celebration || Republic Cultural Centre, Republic Polytechnic |- | 2012 || 9 December || EOY Cosplay Festival 2012 || [[Marina Barrage]] |- | 2013 || 15 December || EOY Cosplay Festival 2013 || Marina Barrage |- | 2014 || 2–3 August || EOY Cosplay Festival 2014 || Marina Barrage |- | 2015 || 15–16 August || EOY Cosplay Festival 2015 || Marina Barrage |- | 2016 || 10–11 December || EOY Cosplay Festival 2016 || Marina Barrage |}
== Mascot == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:EOY2013 Map Yume.jpg|thumb|right|Map of EOY Cosplay Festival 2013 featuring mascot Kyouyaku Yume]] -->
Kyouyaku Yume is a blue-haired girl with no recollection of her identity and past. With a vaguely written clue and a turquoise pebble which she found on herself when she awoke, she goes on a journey of self-discovery.
Yume is specially created by Daiyaku, a Singapore-based art group, for EOY. She is a representation of how the artists believe that people can discover their identity, talents and purpose in life through meeting people and courage to experience new things.<ref name="EOY Mascot Yume">{{cite web | url = http://www.theeoy.com/yume | title = About Yume | publisher = TheEOY.com | accessdate = 19 February 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101118081913/http://www.theeoy.com/yume | archivedate = 18 November 2010 | df = }}</ref>

The '''Editta Braun Company''' is an award-winning dance company founded in [[Salzburg, Austria]] in 1989 by the Austrian choreographer,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Zx_sAAAAMAAJ&q=editta+braun++dance&dq=editta+braun++dance&hl=en&sa=X&ei=SUnuUpi4L8Xj2AXWs4HQDA&ved=0CFQQ6AEwBg World Ballet and Dance] Bent Schonberg, Elizabeth Charman, Sanjoy Roy</ref> dancer and dance instructor [[Editta Braun]]. Members of the multi-national team include dancers, composers, dramatic advisors and light designers. The Editta Braun Company’s work pursues political themes, including intercultural communication and feminist questions. The company is particularly known for the ''body theatre'' performance pieces ''Lufus'', ''Luvos, vol. 2'', and ''planet LUVOS''. The Editta Braun Company has toured in Europe, Asia, Africa and performs at both large and specialty festivals.<ref>[http://www.progvisions.net/reviews_uk/zab_min_uk.htm "album review Zaboitzeff & Crew - Miniaturen: Zoydian suite in three movements - 2000"]. ''Progvisions''.</ref>
== History ==
Braun was one of a group of students who formed the dance collective Vorgänge 1982. She founded her own company shortly before the group broke up in 1989.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=1fDaAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA70&dq=editta+braun++dance&hl=en&sa=X&ei=SUnuUpi4L8Xj2AXWs4HQDA&ved=0CEYQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=editta%20braun%20%20dance&f=false World Encyclopedia of Contemporary Theatre: Volume 1: Europe, Volume 1] edited by Peter Nagy, Phillippe Rouyer, Don Rubin</ref> In 1996, French composer and musician [[Thierry Zaboitzeff]] began creating sound tracks to accompany the group's productions; most have been released as albums.<ref>[http://www.progvisions.net/reviews_uk/zab_min_uk.htm "album review: Zaboitzeff & Crew - Miniaturen: Zoydian suite in three movements - 2000"]. ''ProgVisions'', José Nafría - October 2000</ref><ref>[http://www.expose.org/index.php/articles/display/thierry-zaboitzeff-planet-luvos-3.html "José Nafría - October 2000 "Thierry Zaboitzeff — Planet Luvos (Booster BTZ972, 2012, CD)"]. ''Exposé'', by Peter Thelen, 2013-09-21</ref> Thomas Hinterberger and Peter Thalhamer have designed the lighting for many pieces.
The company collaborated with Egyptian director Mahmoud Aboudoma and his drama ensemble to create ''Coppercity 2001'', based on one of the tales from 1001 Nights.
In 2002, the company began to incorporate texts into their productions, for example, Manfred Wöhlcke’s sociological essay Soziale Entropie and literary variations of the Arthur myth. In 2004, Austrian author [[Barbara Neuwirth]] wrote the text for ''Zurydike'', a piece which was commissioned for the [[Brucknerfest]] in Linz, and included a chamber orchestra, drama and dance ensemble.
In 2004 the company increased its staff of artistic directors and choreographers to include Arturas Valudskis, Rebecca Murgi, Shlomo Bitton, Teresa Ranieri, Mahmoud Aboudoma, and Robert Pienz.
[[File:1997, Heartbeat, editta braun company.jpg|thumb|1997, Heartbeat, editta braun company]] Over the years, outstanding artists from various disciplines (besides dance: drama, composition, direction, writing, dramaturgy, video, light design) have contributed their creative potential to the company. In the beginning, the company’s dance style was especially influenced by Céline Guillaume and Georg Blaschke, the work together with dance legend [[Jean Babilée]], for whom [[Jean Cocteau]] and [[Roland Petit]] created [[Le jeune homme et la mort]], was particularly sensational, immensely furthering the company’s international acclaim. Composer Peter Valentin contributed his work during this time.
For ten years, dancer Barbara Motschiunik played a main role in each production; in 2006, Anna Maria Müller and Tomaz Simatovic joined the group, joining with Juan Dante and Murillo Bobadilla.
Since 2010, several younger performers have joined the company, including Spela Vodeb, and the many performances have been developed with dramaticist Gerda Poschmann-Reichenau.
== Luvos ==
[[File:2012, Planet, editta braun company.jpg|thumb|2012, Planet, editta braun company]] ''Luvos'' is a series of body theater performances.<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/Arts-and-Culture/Entertainment/Israel-Festival-Reviews "Israel Festival Reviews"]. ''Jerusalem Post'', 05/29/2007</ref> The series premiered in 1985 as "Kollektiv Vorgänge’s Lufus".
Between 2001 and 2012, ''Luvos, vol.2'' was performed worldwide before audiences totalling about 15,000 people, in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv, Thessaloniki, Novosibirsk and Moscow, Marseille, Limassol and Nicosia, Brussels, Tallinn, Kaunas, Riga, Vienna, Salzburg and Linz. In 2012 the piece was performed at the Manipulate Visual Theatre festival in Edinburgh<ref>[http://www.heraldscotland.com/arts_ents/13142712.Puppetry_fuses_with_mixed_media_for_festival/ "Puppetry fuses with mixed media for festival"]. ''The Herald'', Scotland, Mary Brennan, Dance critic / 27 January 2014</ref><ref>[https://www.list.co.uk/article/58018-stephen-mottram-editta-braun-and-duda-paiva-among-the-highlights-of-manipulate-2014/ "Stephen Mottram, Editta Braun and Duda Paiva among the highlights of Manipulate 2014"]. ''The List'', 23 January 2014 Niki Boyle</ref><ref>[http://www.edinburghguide.com/reviews/dance/luvostraversetheatrereviewmanipulatefestival-9844 "Luvos, Traverse Theatre, Review (Manipulate Festival)"]. ''Edinburgh Guide'', By Justine Blundell 05 February 2012</ref>
''planet LUVOS'' was performed in 2012 during the Brucknerfest in Linz and at Manipulate in 2014.
The Etta Braun Company has mounted more than 100 performances or Luvos, and has been reviewed positively in ''Neue Westfälische'',<ref>Anke Gronewold in: Neue Westfälische, Bielefeld, August 2003.</ref> ''Neue Kronenzeitung'',<ref>Andrea Hein in: Neue Kronenzeitung, Klagenfurt, Juli 2001.</ref> and ''TV Bomb''<ref>[http://www.tvbomb.co.uk/2012/02/luvos/ TV Bomb, Edinburgh, February 6, 2012.]</ref>
== Publication ==
In 2009, to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the founding of the editta braun company, the volume [[Tanz Kunst Leben. 20 Jahre editta braun company]], edited by Gerda Poschmann-Reichenau and designed by Bettina Frenzel, was published. It contains reminiscences from people who have accompanied the company on its journey, descriptions and pictures from the dance-theater productions presented in the past 20 years in chronological order, as well as interviews with founder Editta Braun and participating artists.
== Selected full-length productions ==
* 1989: Die Jagd – dance quintet * 1990: Materialien für Tanz & Musik - dance and live music * 1991: Collision - duet * 1992: but kind old sun will know ... – dance theater * 1993: La Vie, c’est contagieux - dance theater * Collision – dance short film * 1994: Voyage à Napoli - dance & rock’n roll live * La Vie, c’est contagieux – video documentation about the creative process involved in making the stage piece * 1995: Titania – search image in movement about Sisi, Empress of Austria, Queen of Hungary * 1996: Im Dschungel des Pianisten – dance fable for young souls * 1997: Heartbeat – concerto for dance & music, op. 1 - duo music and dance * 1998: India * 1999: Miniaturen - dance and live music * 2000: Nebensonnen - quartet * 2001: Luvos, vol. 2 – body illusion theater * 2002: manifest - drama, martial arts, dance * editta braun company in Dakar – video documentation about the creative process involved in making the stage piece manifest * 2003: Tajine – improvisational project with dance, drama, live music * 2004: Eurydike - symbiosis of three genres of the play ‚Eurydike’ from Barbara Neuwirth * 2005: oXalis * 2006: Matches of Time – dance theater * 2007: Coppercity 1001 - dance and drama * e.poration – short film * 2008: Wenn ich einmal tot bin, komme ich ins Paradies - dance and song. * 2009: Abseits * 2010: König Artus * 2011: schluss mit kunst * 2012: planet LUVOS * 2013 currently resident in
== Awards ==
* 1986: Second Prize and Award for Most Innovative Choreography at the Concours Chorégraphique International de Bagnolet in Paris for Lufus for the Kollektiv Vorgänge * 1995: bronze medal at the New York Film Festival for Collision, director Othmar Schmiderer * 2001: Award for Best Direction at the Cairo International Festival for Experimental Theatre for Nebensonnen * 2014: Internationaler Preis für Kunst und Kultur der Stadt Salzburg<ref>Kulturfonds der Stadt Salzburg</ref>
== References ==
{{reflist}} *[https://books.google.com/books?id=s5cnAQAAIAAJ&q=editta+braun++dance&dq=editta+braun++dance&hl=en&sa=X&ei=SUnuUpi4L8Xj2AXWs4HQDA&ved=0CFAQ6AEwBQ Bibliographic Guide to Dance, Volumes 1-3]
== External links ==
{{Commons|Editta braun company}} * [http://www.editta-braun.com Web presence Editta braun company - German] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150820060611/http://www.editta-braun.com/edittabrauncompany_e/home_e.html Web presence Editta braun company - English] * [http://www.kulturfonds.at/PreistraegerInnen-2014.56.0.html Kulturfonds der Stadt Salzburg, Preisträgerinnen 2014 - German]

revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=February 2018}} {{COI|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox company | name = EventPlan Limited | logo = | logo_caption = | native_name_lang = en | type = | traded_as = | industry = | genre = <!-- Only used with media and publishing companies --> | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = United Kingdom, 2000 | founder = Howard Giles | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | location_city = | location_country = | locations = <!-- Number of locations, stores, offices, etc. --> | area_served = | key_people = Eleanore Hill Bruce. <small>Managing director</small> Matthew Howarth <small> Director </small>
| production = | services = Event Historical re-enactment, Event Planning & Management | owner = | num_employees = | homepage = <!-- {{URL|http://www.eventplan.co.uk/}} --> }} '''EventPlan Limited''' was formed in 2000. It is a modest-sized UK-based historical events company that specializes in staging a limited number of living history and live re-enactment displays each year including for the National Trust,local councils and individual historic properties. It is directed by Eleanore Hill-Bruce since January 2016 with many years of previous event experience previously.
==Events== EventPlan has been responsible for staging events including [[The Battle of Orgreave]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Artangel | The Battle of Orgreave|url=http://www.artangel.org.uk/projects/2001/the_battle_of_orgreave|website=artangel.org.uk|publisher=Artangel|accessdate=19 June 2014}}</ref> for [[Jeremy Deller]], [[Artangel]] and [[Channel 4]] in 2001. Although a live event (with just one brief break) The [[Battle of Orgreave]] was filmed in real time by Hollywood director [[Mike Figgis]] for Channel 4's programme of the same name. With a minimum of direction, Figgis' camera crews recorded the action as it unfolded around them, resulting in footage that is very similar to that taken during the actual clash in 1984.
Other events include The Roman Army and Chariot Experience (RACE) in [[Jerash]], Jordan in 2005, and ancient to modern era and multi-period shows for the [[Army Benevolent Fund]], [[British army]] and others. During 2014 commemorative projects include Centenary Great War, 70th, and 75th anniversary World War Two displays.
The company has previously assisted with a number of TV and film productions which include the [[BBC]] series [[D-Day to Berlin]], Historyonics presented by [[Nick Knowles]] and [[Brainiac: History Abuse]] and Tetley Beer's spoof "Gladiator" TV advert. They have also arranged post-production ancient Macedonian war chants for the movie [[Alexander]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{URL|http://www.eventplan.co.uk/}}

{{Culture of the Philippines}} {{Women in society sidebar}} :''This article is about Filipino women who create art in the Philippines. For women as subject of art in the Philippines, see [[Women in Philippine art]].'' '''Filipino women artists''' started contributing to Philippine art when the [[History of the Philippines|Philippines]] was still a colonial province of [[Spanish Empire|Spain]] (1521–1898).<ref name=NCCA/> They have continued to participate as art creators after [[World War II]] through modern times by either following the traditional way of making art or by departing from such tradition by embracing modernism and other modes of expressing themselves through art.
==Spanish era (1521–1898)== ===Sculpting=== The first Filipino woman to achieve a level of prominence in the art world, while the [[Philippines]] was under the management of [[Spain]], was sculptor Pelagia Mendoza y Gotianquin (1867-1939). The first female student at the ''[[Academia de Dibujo y Pintura]]'' (Academy of Drawing and Painting), Mendoza studied sculpting under the mentorship of Agustin Saez and Lorenzo Rocha. Her bust of [[Christopher Columbus]] won an award during the quattrocentenial celebration of the [[Discovery of the Americas]].<ref name=NCCA/>
===Painting=== In the field of painting in the Philippines, the works of art of [[Carmen Zaragoza y Rojas]] became notable. Zaragoza was the painter of the masterpiece known as Dos Inteligentias (literally “Two Intellectuals”, 1892), a painting that won Zaragoza a prize during the 1892 anniversary of Christopher Columbus and his discovery of the Americas. Two years later, during the 1895 Exposicion Regional de Filipinas (1895 Regional Exposition in the Philippines), Zaragoza would be awarded a copper medal for creating two landscapes.<ref name=NCCA>{{cite web|last=Flores|first=Patrick|title=Birthing Women Artists|url=http://www.ncca.gov.ph/about-culture-and-arts/articles-on-c-n-a/article.php?i=58&subcat=13|publisher=National Commission for Culture and the Arts (May 30, 2003)|accessdate=24 November 2013}}</ref>
Other notable Filipino women painters during the time of Zaragoza were Concha Paterno, Adele Paterno, Conception de Montilla, Patricia Reyes, Ana Garcia Plana, Josefa Majo, Concepcion Ortiz, Olimpia Teran de Abella, Rafaella Calanta, and Femina David.<ref name=NCCA/>
Another woman painter who excelled in the field of [[art in the Philippines]] was Paz Paterno. Her important painting known as ''Still Life'' was decorated with native fruits such as [[lanzones]] (''Lansium domesticum''), bananas, [[mabolo]]s (velvet apple, ''Diospyros blancoi''), [[Sugar-apple|atis]] (sugar-apple, the fruit of ''[[Annona squamosa]]''), [[balimbing]]s (carambola or starfruit, fruit of ''[[Averrhoa carambola]]''), [[pili nut]]s, and coconuts.<ref name=NCCA/>
==After World War II (1946-present)== After World War II, new female artists emerged carrying the modernistic themes in their art. Among these artists were painters such as Anita Magsaysay-Ho, the first Filipino woman abstractionist Nena Saguil,<ref name=NCCA/> and Philippine Art Gallery owner Lyd Arguilla. During the 1970s and the 1980s, women printmakers and graphic artists began contributing their works of imagery to the Philippine art scene, such as Brenda Fajardo, Ofelia Gelvezon-Tequi, and Imelda Cajipe-Endaya. This period also saw the emergence of women art collectives in the Philippines such as ''[[Kasibulan]],'' for which these artists where members of. Women sculptors like Agnes Arellano, Julie Lluch, Genera Banzon, and Francesca Enriquez also made their noteworthy impressions to the field of sculpting by creating non-traditional statues.<ref name=NCCA/>
Ofelio Gelvezon-Tequi, a pioneer in the print-making industry, created a notable printed portrait of a widow standing next to the casket of her dead husband. The casket in the image was draped with a [[Philippine flag]], while the widow was standing and holding vigil next to the coffin. Gelvezon-Tequi also produced works made of acrylic-on-paper in 1995. Her masterpieces later focused on portraits of Filipino women such former Philippine President [[Corazon Aquino]], the assassins of her husband [[Benigno Aquino, Jr.]], and about plotters of [[coup d'etat]]s.<ref name=NCCA/>
As a mixed-media artist, Brenda Fajardo used art to describe folk magic and [[Philippine mythology|folklore]] of the [[Aeta people|Sulod people]] (part of the Aeta ethnic group) of [[Panay]] province.<ref name=NCCA/> Fajardo is a member of Faculty of Arts at the [[University of the Philippines]] in [[Diliman]], [[Quezon City]]. She was also the curator of the Vargas Museum of Art located inside the Diliman campus of the University of the Philippines. She was a visiting professor at the St. Norbert College in the United States.<ref name=VIA>{{cite web|last=Boyer|first=Robert|title=Two Women Artists: Strong Filipino Women (5)|url=http://www.viatimes.com/_archive/vt_1204/philippines.html|publisher=VIA Times|accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref>
On the other hand, Nena Saguil (died in 1994) expressed her artistry through the use of pen and ink to draw abstract images employing dots, bubble, vortices, and rays, including an imagery of an "enlarged [[hymen]]" and "a woman cleaning a toilet bowl splattered with human excrement".<ref name=NCCA/> Saguil moved to France to live in Paris.<ref name=NCCA/>
Imelda Cajipe-Endaya ventured in making fragmented artistic scenes by recycling materials found in the household to depict the life and responsibilities of the Filipina domestic helper working in the Philippines and abroad, to integrate their unseen roles as the working wife, mother, and daughter while being miles away from their motherland or from their hometowns in the Philippines.<ref name=NCCA/>
[[Paulina Constancia]] is considered one of the most prolific and inspiring female artists in Cebu, Philippines. She is a multifaceted artist best known for her bright colored, whimsical narratives painted on quilts and tiles that are also reflected in her writing. Paulina has exhibited her art in the Philippines, Indonesia, the Netherlands, Mexico & in various cities in the United States & Canada. In 1997, she was presented by the [http://reocities.com/CollegePark/quad/1490/iii1cen1.htm Philippine Centennial Coordinating Council of Northeast USA] in a show called "Here's to Sunny!" at the Philippine Center in New York City. In 2000, her collection of painted quilts called "Kleur en ik in de geheime tuin /Hue & I in a Secret Garden" was presented by the [http://www.haarlemmermeer.nl/gemeenteraad/Millenniumdoelen/Vereniging_Haarlemmermeer_Cebu VHC-Vereniging Haarlemmermeer-Cebu] (sister cities organization of Haarlemmermeer and Cebu) at the Centrum voor Kunst en Cultuur in Hoofddrop and Kunst 2001 Gallery in Badhoevedorp.
Another noteworthy Filipino woman artist was painter<ref name=VIA/> and sculptor Elsie "Inday" Cadapan whose 1997 sculpture was unveiled for display by former Philippine President [[Corazon Aquino]] on October 30, 1997 at the front lobby of the [[Government Service Insurance System]] (GSIS) building. <ref>{{cite web|last=Torrevillas|first=Domini M.|title=GSIS giving artist a bad deal?|url=http://www.philstar.com/opinion/179254/gsis-giving-artist-bad-deal|work=From the Stands|publisher=philSTAR.com (October 10, 2002)|accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref>
==Art as rehabilitation tool== On April 21, 2012, the Thomson Reuters Foundation reported that Alma Quinto launched the "House of Comfort Art Project", a program of the House of Comfort Art Network (ARTHOC), a non-governmental organization that uses art to help sexually abused Filipino women and girls through their rehabilitation. The project employs the use of scrap materials to teach women how to create miniature houses, as a means of expressing their feelings long after the occurrence of abuse and build positive experiences in their minds and to once again become in control of their bodies.<ref>{{cite web|last=Rebekah|first=Curtis|title=Sexually abused Filipino women find solace in art|url=http://www.trust.org/item/20120421161400-f1bzu/|publisher=Thomson Reuters Foundation (21 April 2012)|accessdate=25 November 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|Women of the Philippines}}

{{DEFAULTSORT:Filipino Women Artists}} [[Category:Filipino women artists| ]] [[Category:Women in the Philippines]] [[Category:Feminism and the arts]]

A '''film sculptor''' is employed within the [[art department]] of a [[feature film]].
Their skills are and can be used to create any number of different things from giant rocks in a landscape or oversized stone blocks cladding the facade of a castle to statuary and ornate panelling, to more specialized pieces such as a vehicle hull for a [[fantasy]] film used in [[set construction]]. The material often utilised for large-scale rocks or columns is [[polystyrene]] because it is light and can be carved easily using a hot wire. Polystyrene can also be used to sculpt mid-sized items that are difficult to build in wood and too large for clay - an item such as a moulded chair can then be cast with [[plaster]] and reproduced in [[fibre-glass]]. [[Clay]] modelling is still preferable for any item needing detail and is always used for smaller and finer work.<ref>[http://www.ideastap.com/ideasmag/the-knowledge/jonathan-moore-sculptor Film-set sculptor, By Annika Kristensen 20/12/10 ]</ref><ref>[http://creativeskillset.org/job_roles_and_stories/job_roles/747_sculptor creativeskillset.org, Sculptor]</ref>
==Film sculptors== * [[Keith Short]] * [[John Blakeley]] * [[Sam Demke]]

page.title: First Open Youth European Delphic Games
